passage_text:
Hummingbirds
    
    
        Birds live all around the world. They come in many sizes and colors. Some birds are very big, and some are very small. Hummingbirds are some of the smallest birds on Earth. The bee hummingbird is only two inches long. It weighs less than a penny!
Hummingbirds are amazing little animals. They can flap their wings up to 90 times in one second. That is so fast that their wings look like a blur. It is hard to see their wings because they move so quickly. These tiny birds can hover in the air like a helicopter. They can also fly backwards and upside-down. No other birds can do this!

---

Hummingbirds fly from flower to flower like busy bees. They use their long, pointy beaks to drink sweet nectar from flowers. Nectar is a sugary liquid that gives them lots of energy. Since they flap their wings so much, they need to eat a lot of food. A hummingbird will visit hundreds of flowers every day. It drinks more than its own weight in nectar! They also eat small insects they find on the flowers.
These birds love red flowers the most. People hang red feeders filled with sugary water to attract them. The feeders are dyed red because hummingbirds are drawn to this bright color. Many people enjoy watching these fast little birds at their feeders.

---

Many hummingbirds migrate to different places during the year. The ruby-throated hummingbird lives in the eastern United States during spring and summer. When autumn comes, it flies south to warmer places. This tiny bird makes an incredible journey. It flies 500 miles across the Gulf of Mexico without stopping! From there, it may continue south through Mexico to Costa Rica and other countries.
Hummingbird nests are very small. They are about half the size of a walnut shell. The birds make their nests using tiny pieces of moss and leaves. They use spider webs to hold everything together. The spider web works like glue because it is sticky. It is also flexible, which means it can stretch and bend.

---

A hummingbird lays two tiny eggs in its nest. When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger. This helps keep the babies warm and safe as they get larger. The mother bird feeds her babies insects and sweet nectar. These amazing little birds are some of the most interesting creatures you can find!
question: In Section 1, what does the word hover mean when describing how hummingbirds fly?
option_1: stay in one spot in the air
option_2: move very quickly forward
option_3: fly in circles around
option_4: land on top of
option_1_explanation: Correct! The text compares hovering to a helicopter, which stays in one place in the air without moving forward. The passage explains that hummingbirds 'can hover in the air like a helicopter,' which means staying still in one spot while flying. This shows you understand how the word hover describes a special way hummingbirds can fly.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage does mention that hummingbirds fly quickly, but 'hover' means something different than moving forward fast. Reread the sentence that says hummingbirds 'can hover in the air like a helicopter.' Think about what a helicopter does when it hovers - it stays in one place rather than moving quickly forward.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. While hummingbirds do fly to many flowers, 'hover' doesn't mean flying in circles. Look at the comparison in the text: 'hover in the air like a helicopter.' Consider what a helicopter does when it hovers - it remains still in one spot, not circling around.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. Hovering is a type of flying, not landing. The passage says hummingbirds 'can hover in the air,' which tells you they are still flying, not resting on something. The text compares hovering to what a helicopter does - staying in the air without landing.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 1 about hovering behavior - differs from reference which asks about 'flexible' in Section 3 related to nest materials
homogeneity_check: all choices are actions or positions in the air
specificity_check: all describe specific flying or positioning behaviors
length_check: A: 6 words, B: 4 words, C: 4 words, D: 3 words - within acceptable range
semantic_distance_check: no synonyms - each describes distinctly different motion or position
single_correct_check: only A matches the helicopter comparison and meaning of hover
diversity_check: targets Section 1 hovering behavior - completely different from reference about flexibility and other variants

question: Based on Section 2, what does the word attract mean when the text says feeders 'attract' hummingbirds?
option_1: bring birds closer or draw them in
option_2: give food and water to birds
option_3: keep birds away from an area
option_4: teach birds where to find food
option_1_explanation: Correct! The passage explains that people hang red feeders 'to attract them,' meaning to draw hummingbirds near or bring them closer. The text also says 'hummingbirds are drawn to this bright color,' which helps you understand that attract means to pull or bring something closer. You correctly used context clues to determine the word's meaning.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. While feeders do give food to hummingbirds, that's not what 'attract' means. The passage says people hang feeders 'to attract them,' which describes why people use feeders, not what the feeders contain. Look at the phrase 'hummingbirds are drawn to this bright color' to help you understand what attract means.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect - attract means the opposite of keeping away. The passage explains that people want hummingbirds to come to their feeders, not stay away from them. Notice the text says 'hummingbirds are drawn to this bright color,' which suggests movement toward something, not away from it.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. Teaching is about learning, but 'attract' describes pulling or drawing something closer. The sentence says people hang red feeders 'to attract them,' meaning to bring hummingbirds near. Look at the related phrase 'hummingbirds are drawn to this bright color' to understand that attract is about drawing something closer.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 2 about feeders attracting birds - differs from reference which asks about 'flexible' in Section 3 about nest construction

question: According to Section 3, what does the word incredible mean when describing the hummingbird's journey?
option_1: very long and boring
option_2: amazingly impressive or hard to believe
option_3: short and easy to complete
option_4: dangerous and frightening for birds
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage describes the journey as 'incredible' right before explaining that the bird flies 500 miles without stopping, which is impressive, not boring. When something is incredible, it causes wonder or amazement. Reread how the author describes this long flight to understand why it would be amazing rather than boring.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The text calls the journey 'incredible' and then explains the bird flies 500 miles across the Gulf of Mexico without stopping - something that is amazingly hard to believe for such a tiny bird. The word incredible shows the author thinks this journey is remarkably impressive. You correctly used the context about the 500-mile non-stop flight to understand this word means something amazing or hard to believe.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage describes a 500-mile flight without stopping, which is definitely not short or easy. The author uses 'incredible' to emphasize how remarkable this journey is. Think about what makes a tiny bird flying 500 miles without rest - that would be impressive and difficult, not short and easy.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. While the journey might be challenging, 'incredible' focuses on how impressive or amazing something is, not how dangerous it is. The passage emphasizes the remarkable distance (500 miles without stopping) to show why the journey is incredible. The word expresses amazement at what the bird can accomplish.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 3 about migration journey - differs from reference which asks about 'flexible' related to spider web nest material

specificity_check: all describe characteristics of trips or travels

question: In Section 1, what does the word blur mean when the text says the wings 'look like a blur'?
option_1: something moving too fast to see clearly
option_2: something that makes a loud sound
option_3: something very colorful and bright
option_4: something very tiny and small
option_1_explanation: Correct! The passage explains that hummingbirds flap their wings up to 90 times per second, which is 'so fast that their wings look like a blur.' The next sentence confirms this meaning: 'It is hard to see their wings because they move so quickly.' You correctly used these context clues to understand that blur describes something moving too fast to see clearly.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. A blur is about how something looks, not how it sounds. The passage says the wings 'look like a blur' and explains 'it is hard to see their wings because they move so quickly.' This tells you blur is about vision and seeing, not about hearing sounds. Focus on the word 'look' to understand blur describes appearance.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. While the passage does mention colors in other parts, 'blur' doesn't mean colorful. The text explains the wings 'look like a blur' because they flap up to 90 times per second, making them 'hard to see' due to fast movement. Blur describes unclear vision from speed, not bright colors.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage does say hummingbirds are tiny, but 'blur' means something different. Look at the full context: wings flap 90 times per second, 'so fast that their wings look like a blur,' and 'hard to see their wings because they move so quickly.' This shows blur is about fast movement making things hard to see, not about size.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 1 about wing movement appearing as blur - differs from reference which asks about 'flexible' in Section 3 about nest materials

specificity_check: all describe specific qualities or properties

question: Based on the information in the passage, what is the author's main feeling about hummingbirds?
option_1: worried that they might become extinct
option_2: fascinated by their abilities and features
option_3: concerned that they eat too many insects
option_4: disappointed that they only like red flowers
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. The author never mentions extinction or expresses worry about hummingbirds disappearing. Throughout the passage, the author uses positive words like 'amazing,' 'incredible,' and 'interesting' to describe hummingbirds. The tone is excited and informative, not worried or concerned about their survival.
option_2_explanation: Correct! Throughout the passage, the author uses words like 'amazing,' 'incredible,' and 'interesting' to describe hummingbirds and their abilities. The author shares many impressive facts about their flying, eating, migrating, and nest-building, showing fascination and wonder. The enthusiastic tone and choice to highlight remarkable features reveals the author's admiration for these birds.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. The author mentions that hummingbirds eat insects, but presents this as a neutral fact, not a concern. The passage focuses on positive, amazing features of hummingbirds using words like 'amazing' and 'incredible.' There is no negative language suggesting the author is worried about their insect consumption.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The author simply states that hummingbirds 'love red flowers the most' as an interesting fact, not as a disappointment. The overall tone is positive and informative, using words like 'amazing,' 'incredible,' and 'interesting' to share remarkable facts about hummingbirds. Nothing in the passage suggests the author is disappointed by their flower preferences.

question: What does the author think is most important for readers to understand about hummingbirds?
option_1: They are expensive pets to keep at home.
option_2: They have many special and unusual qualities.
option_3: They are more beautiful than other bird species.
option_4: They need protection from harmful predators.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage never mentions keeping hummingbirds as pets or discusses costs. The author focuses on sharing interesting facts about wild hummingbirds - their flying abilities, eating habits, migration, and nesting. The purpose is educational, teaching about hummingbirds in nature, not about pet care.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The author dedicates the entire passage to explaining unique features of hummingbirds: their tiny size, special flying abilities (hovering, backwards, upside-down), incredible migration, and clever nest-building. Words like 'amazing,' 'incredible,' and 'interesting' emphasize these special qualities. The author's point of view is that hummingbirds are remarkable creatures worth learning about because of their unusual characteristics.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. While the passage mentions colors of flowers and feeders, the author never compares hummingbird beauty to other birds or claims they are more beautiful. The author's focus is on their unique abilities and behaviors - flying skills, eating habits, migration, and nesting - not on ranking their appearance against other species.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage does not mention predators or dangers facing hummingbirds. The author's point of view focuses on celebrating and teaching about hummingbirds' amazing abilities like hovering, migrating 500 miles, and building stretchy nests. The tone is informative and admiring, not concerned about protection needs.
differentiation_notes: Targets author's central message about what matters most - differs from reference which asks about author's reason for writing

specificity_check: all describe specific ideas author might want to convey

question: How would the author most likely respond to someone who says hummingbirds are just ordinary birds?
option_1: agree that most birds have similar abilities
option_2: explain the many ways hummingbirds are unique
option_3: suggest studying larger birds instead of small ones
option_4: recommend reading different books about common birds
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. The author would definitely disagree with this statement. Throughout the passage, the author emphasizes how hummingbirds are different from other birds, stating 'No other birds can do this!' about their flying abilities. The author's point of view celebrates what makes hummingbirds special, not what makes them similar to other birds.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The entire passage demonstrates the author's point of view that hummingbirds are extraordinary, not ordinary. The author provides many examples of unique features: hovering, flying backwards and upside-down ('No other birds can do this!'), 500-mile non-stop migration, and stretchy spider-web nests. The author would use these facts to show why hummingbirds are special and remarkable.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. The author clearly values learning about small hummingbirds, dedicating the entire passage to their amazing features. The author uses words like 'amazing,' 'incredible,' and 'interesting' to show enthusiasm for these tiny birds. Nothing in the passage suggests the author thinks larger birds are more worthy of study.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The author's point of view is that hummingbirds are fascinating and worth learning about, not common or ordinary. By sharing facts about their unique flying, eating, migrating, and nesting, the author shows these birds deserve attention. The author would want people to learn more about hummingbirds, not read about different birds instead.

The spider web works like glue because it is sticky. It is also flexible, which means it can stretch and bend.

---

A hummingbird lays two tiny eggs in its nest. When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger. This helps keep the babies warm and safe as they get larger. The mother bird feeds her babies insects and sweet nectar. These amazing little birds are some of the most interesting creatures you can find!
question: Which statement best describes the author's opinion about people who put up hummingbird feeders?
option_1: They are helping scientists study bird behavior.
option_2: They are wasting money on unnecessary items.
option_3: They enjoy observing these remarkable little birds.
option_4: They need to learn more about proper bird care.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage mentions that 'many people enjoy watching these fast little birds at their feeders,' but never discusses scientific study or research. The author's point of view is that people put up feeders for personal enjoyment, not to help scientists. Focus on why the author says people use feeders.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. The author presents feeder use positively, not negatively. The passage states 'Many people enjoy watching these fast little birds at their feeders,' showing the author views this as a pleasant activity. The author's tone throughout is enthusiastic about hummingbirds, suggesting approval of people who want to observe them at feeders.
option_3_explanation: Correct! The author states 'Many people enjoy watching these fast little birds at their feeders,' directly revealing the belief that people put up feeders because they find pleasure in observing hummingbirds. This aligns with the author's overall point of view that hummingbirds are 'amazing,' 'incredible,' and 'interesting' creatures worthy of attention and appreciation.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The author never suggests people need more education about feeders or bird care. The passage simply explains that people hang feeders and 'enjoy watching these fast little birds.' The author's tone is positive and informative, not critical of people who put up feeders. There is no indication the author thinks they are doing something wrong.

passage_text:
Hummingbirds
    
    
        Birds live all around the world. They come in many sizes and colors. Some birds are very big, and some are very small. Hummingbirds are some of the smallest birds on Earth. The bee hummingbird is only two inches long. It weighs less than a penny!
Hummingbirds are amazing little animals. They can flap their wings up to 90 times in one second. That is so fast that their wings look like a blur. It is hard to see their wings because they move so quickly. These tiny birds can hover in the air like a helicopter. They can also fly backwards and upside-down. No other birds can do this!

---

Hummingbirds fly from flower to flower like busy bees. They use their long, pointy beaks to drink sweet nectar from flowers. Nectar is a sugary liquid that gives them lots of energy. Since they flap their wings so much, they need to eat a lot of food. A hummingbird will visit hundreds of flowers every day. It drinks more than its own weight in nectar! They also eat small insects they find on the flowers.
These birds love red flowers the most. People hang red feeders filled with sugary water to attract them. The feeders are dyed red because hummingbirds are drawn to this bright color. Many people enjoy watching these fast little birds at their feeders.

---

Many hummingbirds migrate to different places during the year. The ruby-throated hummingbird lives in the eastern United States during spring and summer. When autumn comes, it flies south to warmer places. This tiny bird makes an incredible journey. It flies 500 miles across the Gulf of Mexico without stopping! From there, it may continue south through Mexico to Costa Rica and other countries.
Hummingbird nests are very small. They are about half the size of a walnut shell. The birds make their nests using tiny pieces of moss and leaves. They use spider webs to hold everything together. The spider web works like glue because it is sticky. It is also flexible, which means it can stretch and bend.

---

A hummingbird lays two tiny eggs in its nest. When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger. This helps keep the babies warm and safe as they get larger. The mother bird feeds her babies insects and sweet nectar. These amazing little birds are some of the most interesting creatures you can find!
question: According to the passage, why do hummingbirds need to drink more than their own weight in nectar?
option_1: because nectar helps them grow bigger and stronger
option_2: because they use so much energy flapping their wings
option_3: because they share nectar with their baby birds
option_4: because they store nectar for their long migration
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage doesn't say nectar helps hummingbirds grow. Look at the sentences: 'Since they flap their wings so much, they need to eat a lot of food.' The text directly connects wing flapping to their need for food, not growth. The nectar provides energy for their constant movement, not for getting bigger.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The passage explains 'Since they flap their wings so much, they need to eat a lot of food' and 'Nectar is a sugary liquid that gives them lots of energy.' You correctly connected the cause (flapping wings up to 90 times per second uses energy) to the effect (needing to drink large amounts of nectar). This shows you understand the relationship between their wing movement and food needs.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. While the passage mentions mother birds feed babies insects and nectar, it doesn't say this is why hummingbirds drink more than their weight in nectar. The text clearly states 'Since they flap their wings so much, they need to eat a lot of food.' The large nectar consumption is connected to their own wing flapping, not sharing with babies.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage doesn't mention storing nectar for migration. The text explains 'Since they flap their wings so much, they need to eat a lot of food.' The reason for drinking so much nectar is their constant, rapid wing movement (up to 90 times per second), which requires lots of energy. They need the nectar immediately for energy, not for storage.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 2 cause-effect between wing flapping and nectar consumption - differs from reference which asks about visiting hundreds of flowers
homogeneity_check: all choices are reasons or purposes for drinking nectar
specificity_check: all describe specific causes for high nectar consumption
length_check: A: 8 words, B: 9 words, C: 8 words, D: 8 words - perfectly balanced
semantic_distance_check: no synonyms - each represents different reason for drinking nectar
single_correct_check: only B matches the stated cause-effect of wing flapping needing energy
diversity_check: targets wing-flapping energy relationship in Section 2 - different from reference about visiting flowers

question: Based on Section 1, how does being able to fly backwards and upside-down help hummingbirds?
option_1: It allows them to escape from dangerous predators quickly.
option_2: It helps them reach nectar in flowers more easily.
option_3: It makes their wings look like a blur to observers.
option_4: It lets them build nests in hard-to-reach places.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage doesn't mention predators or danger. option_2_explanation: Correct! Although not stated directly, you can infer this answer by connecting information from different parts of the passage. Section 1 describes their special flying abilities (hovering, backwards, upside-down), and Section 2 explains they 'fly from flower to flower' to drink nectar. These unusual flying skills would help them maneuver around flowers in different positions to reach nectar effectively.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage explains that rapid wing flapping (up to 90 times per second) makes wings look like a blur, not flying backwards or upside-down. These are two different abilities mentioned in Section 1. Flying backwards and upside-down are special movements that help hummingbirds, while the blur effect is just what happens when they flap so fast.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage describes nest-building in Section 3 but never connects it to flying backwards or upside-down. The text explains nests are built with moss, leaves, and spider webs, but doesn't say these flying skills help with nest construction. Look at Section 2, which connects their flying abilities to visiting flowers for nectar.

question: Why do people fill hummingbird feeders with sugary water instead of plain water?
option_1: because plain water would freeze during cold weather
option_2: because hummingbirds cannot see or find plain water
option_3: because sugary water is similar to the nectar they need
option_4: because plain water is too heavy for them to drink

People use sugary water because it replaces the natural nectar hummingbirds need for energy, not because of weather concerns.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage doesn't suggest hummingbirds have trouble seeing plain water. Section 2 explains they naturally drink nectar, which is 'a sugary liquid that gives them lots of energy.' The feeders contain sugar water to mimic this natural food source that provides the energy hummingbirds need for their rapid wing flapping, not because of vision issues.
option_3_explanation: Correct! The passage explains that hummingbirds naturally 'drink sweet nectar from flowers' and 'Nectar is a sugary liquid that gives them lots of energy.' By connecting this information, you can understand that people use sugary water in feeders because it imitates the natural nectar that provides the energy hummingbirds need. This shows you made an inference by linking the description of nectar to the purpose of feeder contents.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage never suggests that weight is a concern for hummingbird drinking. In fact, the text states 'A hummingbird will visit hundreds of flowers every day. It drinks more than its own weight in nectar!' This shows they can drink large amounts. People use sugar water because it matches the nectar that gives hummingbirds energy, not because of weight issues.

question: What can you conclude about why ruby-throated hummingbirds leave the eastern United States in autumn?
option_1: They follow other types of birds that are migrating south.
option_2: They need to find warmer places with available food sources.
option_3: They want to build their nests in tropical rainforest trees.
option_4: They are searching for red flowers that only bloom in winter.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage never mentions ruby-throated hummingbirds following other birds during migration. The text explains they fly to 'warmer places' but doesn't suggest they travel in groups with other species. You need to use information about what hummingbirds need (flowers for nectar, insects) and connect it to why they would leave when autumn comes.
option_2_explanation: Correct! While not stated directly, you can conclude this by combining multiple pieces of evidence. The passage says hummingbirds need nectar from flowers for energy, fly to 'warmer places' when autumn comes, and continue 'south through Mexico to Costa Rica.' In autumn, flowers die in cold weather, so hummingbirds must travel to warm places where flowers still grow and provide nectar. This inference requires connecting their food needs to seasonal changes.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. Section 3 mentions nest-building but says nests are built where they live during 'spring and summer,' not in the places they migrate to. The passage states they fly to warmer places 'when autumn comes,' which is after nesting season. Migration happens when they leave their nesting grounds, not when they go to build nests elsewhere.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. While the passage mentions hummingbirds love red flowers, it doesn't say they migrate to find flowers that only bloom in winter. The text explains they fly to 'warmer places' and you must infer this is because they need flowers (which don't grow in cold autumn/winter weather up north) to provide the nectar they depend on for energy.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 3 requiring inference about why migration occurs by connecting multiple facts - differs from reference about flower visits

specificity_check: all describe specific purposes for leaving and traveling south

question: What happens right after a hummingbird lays eggs in the nest?
option_1: The spider web stretches to make the nest larger.
option_2: The mother bird feeds the babies insects and nectar.
option_3: The eggs sit in the nest until they hatch.
option_4: The babies start to grow inside the tiny nest.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. You need to follow the sequence carefully. The passage states 'When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger.' The stretching happens after the babies hatch and grow, not right after the eggs are laid. First eggs are laid, then they hatch, then babies grow, then the nest stretches. Look for the correct order of events.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage explains 'The mother bird feeds her babies insects and sweet nectar,' but this happens after the babies hatch. The sequence is: eggs are laid, eggs hatch, babies grow, mother feeds them. You need to identify what comes immediately after laying eggs, which is waiting for them to hatch, not feeding the babies yet.
option_3_explanation: Correct! Following the sequence in Section 3, the passage explains: first 'A hummingbird lays two tiny eggs in its nest,' then 'When the babies hatch and start to grow' other things happen. Between laying eggs and hatching, the eggs must sit in the nest. You correctly identified the immediate next step in the sequence of events by understanding that eggs must be incubated before hatching occurs.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage states 'When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches.' The babies growing happens after they hatch, not right after the eggs are laid. The correct sequence is: eggs laid  eggs hatch  babies grow. What happens right after laying is that the eggs remain in the nest until they are ready to hatch.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 3 sequence step immediately after egg-laying - differs from reference which asks what happens before nest growth

option_1: The spider web must stretch to make room for feeding.

option_2_explanation: Correct! The passage presents a clear sequence in Section 3: 'A hummingbird lays two tiny eggs in its nest. You correctly identified this essential prerequisite by analyzing the cause-and-effect relationship in the sequence of events.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage explains that nest-building with moss and leaves happens before eggs are laid, not before feeding babies. The sequence is: build nest  lay eggs  eggs hatch  feed babies. Collecting nest materials is much earlier in the process. What must happen immediately before feeding is that babies must hatch from the eggs.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage describes migration in Section 3 but doesn't connect it to the feeding sequence. The text explains nest-building, egg-laying, hatching, and feeding all happen during 'spring and summer' when ruby-throated hummingbirds 'live in the eastern United States,' before they migrate. Migration happens after nesting season. Focus on the sequence within the nesting process.

The spider web works like glue because it is sticky. It is also flexible, which means it can stretch and bend.

---

A hummingbird lays two tiny eggs in its nest. When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger. This helps keep the babies warm and safe as they get larger. The mother bird feeds her babies insects and sweet nectar. These amazing little birds are some of the most interesting creatures you can find!
question: Why does the spider web need to be both sticky and flexible for the hummingbird nest?
option_1: Sticky holds materials together, and flexible allows the nest to stretch as babies grow.
option_2: Sticky attracts insects for food, and flexible makes the nest comfortable for babies.
option_3: Sticky helps the nest stick to tree branches, and flexible keeps it from breaking in wind.
option_4: Sticky prevents eggs from rolling out, and flexible helps the mother bird shape the nest.
option_1_explanation: Correct! The passage explains two important properties of spider webs and their purposes: 'The spider web works like glue because it is sticky' (holding materials together) and 'It is also flexible, which means it can stretch and bend. When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger.' You successfully analyzed how both characteristics serve specific functions in nest construction and use.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage never says spider webs attract insects to the nest. While the text explains 'The spider web works like glue because it is sticky' and 'It is also flexible, which means it can stretch,' the purpose of flexibility is 'When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger,' not comfort. The web's stickiness is for holding materials together, not attracting food.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage doesn't mention attaching nests to branches or protecting them from wind. The text explains the spider web 'works like glue because it is sticky' to hold nest materials (moss and leaves) together, and 'it is also flexible' so 'the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger' as babies grow. Both properties relate to nest construction and expansion, not attachment or weather protection.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage never mentions eggs rolling out or the mother shaping the nest. The text clearly states the spider web 'works like glue because it is sticky' to hold materials together, and describes flexibility's purpose: 'When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger.' Both properties work together for building and expanding the nest structure.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 3 analyzing dual properties of spider web and their functions - differs from reference about single property (flexible)
homogeneity_check: all choices pair two properties with two purposes
specificity_check: all provide specific reasons for both sticky and flexible qualities
length_check: A: 15 words, B: 14 words, C: 15 words, D: 14 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: no synonyms - each pair represents different dual functions
single_correct_check: only A matches both stated purposes: glue-like holding and stretching for growth
diversity_check: targets complex dual-property analysis in Section 3 - different from reference and variants 1-2

passage_text:
Hummingbirds
    
    
        Birds live all around the world. They come in many sizes and colors. Some birds are very big, and some are very small. Hummingbirds are some of the smallest birds on Earth. The bee hummingbird is only two inches long. It weighs less than a penny!
Hummingbirds are amazing little animals. They can flap their wings up to 90 times in one second. That is so fast that their wings look like a blur. It is hard to see their wings because they move so quickly. These tiny birds can hover in the air like a helicopter. They can also fly backwards and upside-down. No other birds can do this!

---

Hummingbirds fly from flower to flower like busy bees. They use their long, pointy beaks to drink sweet nectar from flowers. Nectar is a sugary liquid that gives them lots of energy. Since they flap their wings so much, they need to eat a lot of food. A hummingbird will visit hundreds of flowers every day. It drinks more than its own weight in nectar! They also eat small insects they find on the flowers.
These birds love red flowers the most. People hang red feeders filled with sugary water to attract them. The feeders are dyed red because hummingbirds are drawn to this bright color. Many people enjoy watching these fast little birds at their feeders.

---

Many hummingbirds migrate to different places during the year. The ruby-throated hummingbird lives in the eastern United States during spring and summer. When autumn comes, it flies south to warmer places. This tiny bird makes an incredible journey. It flies 500 miles across the Gulf of Mexico without stopping! From there, it may continue south through Mexico to Costa Rica and other countries.
Hummingbird nests are very small. They are about half the size of a walnut shell. The birds make their nests using tiny pieces of moss and leaves. They use spider webs to hold everything together. The spider web works like glue because it is sticky. It is also flexible, which means it can stretch and bend.

---

A hummingbird lays two tiny eggs in its nest. When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger. This helps keep the babies warm and safe as they get larger. The mother bird feeds her babies insects and sweet nectar. These amazing little birds are some of the most interesting creatures you can find!
question: According to Section 3, what is the relationship between the spider web stretching and the baby birds staying safe?
option_1: The stretching web makes noise that warns babies of danger nearby.
option_2: The stretching web creates more space so babies remain warm and protected.
option_3: The stretching web attracts the mother bird back to feed the babies.
option_4: The stretching web signals to other birds that the nest is occupied.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage never mentions noise, sounds, or warnings related to the spider web. The text explains 'When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger. This helps keep the babies warm and safe as they get larger.' The relationship is between stretching creating space and maintaining warmth/safety, not about making warning sounds.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The passage directly connects these ideas in Section 3: 'When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger. This helps keep the babies warm and safe as they get larger.' You correctly identified the cause-effect relationship: stretching creates needed space, which allows the nest to continue protecting growing babies. This shows understanding of how one event (stretching) directly supports another outcome (safety).
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage doesn't say spider web stretching attracts or signals the mother. The text explains the relationship differently: 'the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger. This helps keep the babies warm and safe as they get larger.' The stretching is about creating space for growing babies to remain protected, not about communicating with the mother bird.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The passage never mentions signaling to other birds or indicating nest occupancy. Section 3 clearly states 'the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger. This helps keep the babies warm and safe as they get larger.' The relationship is between stretching (creating more room) and maintaining safety for the growing babies inside, not communication with outside birds.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 3 cause-effect between web stretching and baby safety - differs from reference which asks what precedes nest growth
homogeneity_check: all choices describe relationships between stretching and an outcome
specificity_check: all propose specific causal connections or effects
length_check: A: 11 words, B: 11 words, C: 10 words, D: 10 words - perfectly balanced
semantic_distance_check: no synonyms - each describes different type of relationship
single_correct_check: only B matches the stated purpose of maintaining warmth and safety through space
diversity_check: targets specific cause-effect relationship in Section 3 - different from reference and variants 1-3

passage_text:
The Skeletal System
    
    
        Hello! My name is Dr. Welbody. Some of you may remember me from when you were in first grade. I came to your school to teach you about your body. I told you to eat healthy food so you would grow big and strong. It looks like you listened! You have grown so much since then!
Today I am here to teach you more about your body and how it works. We will learn about three important systems. These are the skeletal system, the muscular system, and the nervous system. Each system has a special job to help your body work.

---

Let's start with the skeletal system. The skeletal system is made up of all the bones in your body. These bones give your body its shape. I have pictures on my computer to show you. You have more than 200 bones in your body! When I went to medical school, I had to learn the name of every single bone. That was very hard work!
Let's begin at the top with your skull. Doctors also call the skull the cranium. Your skull has a very important job. It protects your brain, which is a soft organ inside your head. You might think your skull is one big bone, but it's not! Your skull is actually made of 22 different bones that fit together.

---

Now rub the back of your neck. Can you feel the bone there? That is part of your spine. Your spine is made of more than thirty small bones stacked on top of each other. Each small bone is called a vertebra. All these bones together protect your spinal cord, which sends messages to your brain.
If you tap on your chest, you can feel your breastbone. The medical name for this bone is the sternum. If you tap to the left or right, you might feel your ribs. Your ribs protect important organs like your heart and lungs. The ribs look like a cage around these organs. Behind your ribs are two bones shaped like a triangle. These are your shoulder blade bones. The medical name for shoulder blade is scapula.

---

The pelvis is the group of bones at your hips. In your lower leg, you have two important bones. The tibia is the bigger bone, and the fibula is the smaller one next to it.
Now let's play Simon Says to practice these bone names! When you take a deep breath, watch how your rib cage can expand to make room for air. Your skeletal system works with your muscular system and nervous system to help you move and stay healthy. Are you ready to play?
Simon says, tap your skull! Simon says, now tap your cranium! Did I trick you? They are the same bone! Simon says, bend over and touch your tibia. Simon says, take a deep breath and feel your ribs expand. Now touch your scapula! Wait - I didn't say Simon says!
question: Based on the information in the text, what is the main purpose of the ribs in your body?
option_1: to allow your chest to expand when you breathe deeply
option_2: to protect important organs like your heart and lungs
option_3: to connect your shoulder blades to your breastbone
option_4: to send messages from your body to your brain
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While Dr. Welbody mentions in the Simon Says game that 'your rib cage can expand to make room for air,' this is a function during breathing, not the main purpose. The text clearly states the primary job is protection: 'Your ribs protect important organs like your heart and lungs.' Look for what the text identifies as the bone's main job.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The text explicitly states: 'Your ribs protect important organs like your heart and lungs. The ribs look like a cage around these organs.' This directly answers what the ribs' purpose is. When a passage tells you what something does or its job, that's the key information to use.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The text mentions shoulder blades (scapula) are 'behind your ribs,' but never states that ribs connect these bones. You may be confusing the location of bones with their function. Reread the paragraph about ribs to find what job they actually perform.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. This describes the job of the spinal cord, not the ribs. The text states: 'All these bones together protect your spinal cord, which sends messages to your brain.' Make sure you're matching the correct function to the correct body part.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 4 about rib function - differs from reference which asks about skull/brain protection in paragraph 3. Uses 'Based on' stem vs 'According to' and focuses on ribs rather than skull bones.
homogeneity_check: all choices are functions or purposes of bones/body parts
specificity_check: all describe specific roles or jobs in the body
length_check: A: 10 words, B: 10 words, C: 8 words, D: 10 words - balanced within 25%
semantic_distance_check: each describes distinctly different functions: breathing expansion, organ protection, structural connection, message transmission
single_correct_check: only B is defensible as the text explicitly states ribs protect organs
diversity_check: targets paragraph 4 rib protection - completely different from reference about skull/brain in paragraph 3

option_2_explanation: Correct! The text clearly states: 'Your spine is made of more than thirty small bones stacked on top of each other...All these bones together protect your spinal cord.' option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Two hundred bones is the total number of bones in your entire body, not just in your spine. The text says: 'You have more than 200 bones in your body!' This is about the whole skeletal system, not one specific part. Look for details about individual bone structures.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Two triangle-shaped bones describe your shoulder blades (scapula), not your spine. The text states: 'Behind your ribs are two bones shaped like a triangle.' Make sure you're reading about the correct body part mentioned in the question.

Now rub the back of your neck. Can you feel the bone there? That is part of your spine. Your spine is made of more than thirty small bones stacked on top of each other. Each small bone is called a vertebra. All these bones together protect your spinal cord, which sends messages to your brain.
If you tap on your chest, you can feel your breastbone. The medical name for this bone is the sternum. If you tap to the left or right, you might feel your ribs. Your ribs protect important organs like your heart and lungs. The ribs look like a cage around these organs. Behind your ribs are two bones shaped like a triangle. These are your shoulder blade bones. The medical name for shoulder blade is scapula.

---

The pelvis is the group of bones at your hips. In your lower leg, you have two important bones. The tibia is the bigger bone, and the fibula is the smaller one next to it.
Now let's play Simon Says to practice these bone names! When you take a deep breath, watch how your rib cage can expand to make room for air. Your skeletal system works with your muscular system and nervous system to help you move and stay healthy. Are you ready to play?
Simon says, tap your skull! Simon says, now tap your cranium! Did I trick you? They are the same bone! Simon says, bend over and touch your tibia. Simon says, take a deep breath and feel your ribs expand. Now touch your scapula! Wait - I didn't say Simon says!
question: Dr. Welbody mentions playing Simon Says to practice bone names. What does this activity reveal about how she wants students to learn?
option_1: She believes students learn best when they can move their bodies and interact with the content physically
option_2: She thinks students need to be tricked into learning by disguising lessons as games
option_3: She wants to show that skeletal system knowledge is only useful during game activities

passage_text:
The Skeletal System
    
    
        Hello! My name is Dr. Welbody. Some of you may remember me from when you were in first grade. I came to your school to teach you about your body. I told you to eat healthy food so you would grow big and strong. It looks like you listened! You have grown so much since then!
Today I am here to teach you more about your body and how it works. We will learn about three important systems. These are the skeletal system, the muscular system, and the nervous system. Each system has a special job to help your body work.

---

Let's start with the skeletal system. The skeletal system is made up of all the bones in your body. These bones give your body its shape. I have pictures on my computer to show you. You have more than 200 bones in your body! When I went to medical school, I had to learn the name of every single bone. That was very hard work!
Let's begin at the top with your skull. Doctors also call the skull the cranium. Your skull has a very important job. It protects your brain, which is a soft organ inside your head. You might think your skull is one big bone, but it's not! Your skull is actually made of 22 different bones that fit together.

---

Now rub the back of your neck. Can you feel the bone there? That is part of your spine. Your spine is made of more than thirty small bones stacked on top of each other. Each small bone is called a vertebra. All these bones together protect your spinal cord, which sends messages to your brain.
If you tap on your chest, you can feel your breastbone. The medical name for this bone is the sternum. If you tap to the left or right, you might feel your ribs. Your ribs protect important organs like your heart and lungs. The ribs look like a cage around these organs. Behind your ribs are two bones shaped like a triangle. These are your shoulder blade bones. The medical name for shoulder blade is scapula.

---

The pelvis is the group of bones at your hips. In your lower leg, you have two important bones. The tibia is the bigger bone, and the fibula is the smaller one next to it.
Now let's play Simon Says to practice these bone names! When you take a deep breath, watch how your rib cage can expand to make room for air. Your skeletal system works with your muscular system and nervous system to help you move and stay healthy. Are you ready to play?
Simon says, tap your skull! Simon says, now tap your cranium! Did I trick you? They are the same bone! Simon says, bend over and touch your tibia. Simon says, take a deep breath and feel your ribs expand. Now touch your scapula! Wait - I didn't say Simon says!
question: Based on how Dr. Welbody presents information in the text, what can you conclude about her approach to teaching medical concepts to third graders?
option_1: She simplifies complex anatomy by introducing both common and medical terms gradually
option_2: She focuses only on the most difficult bone names that students must memorize
option_3: She avoids using any medical terminology to prevent confusing young students
option_4: She expects students to learn as much as doctors learn in medical school
option_1_explanation: Correct! Throughout the text, Dr. Welbody introduces common terms first (skull, shoulder blade, breastbone) then adds medical terms (cranium, scapula, sternum), saying things like 'Doctors also call the skull the cranium.' She balances accessibility with proper terminology, making complex concepts manageable. This gradual introduction helps students build vocabulary without being overwhelmed.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Dr. Welbody doesn't focus on difficult namesshe teaches a range from simple (ribs, spine) to complex (scapula, vertebra). She mentions medical school was 'very hard work' but doesn't expect the same level from third graders. Review how she introduces various bones with different complexity levels.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The text clearly shows Dr. Welbody DOES use medical terminologycranium, sternum, scapula, vertebra, tibia, fibula. However, she introduces these alongside common terms to build understanding. She doesn't avoid medical words; she makes them accessible. Reread to see how many medical terms she actually teaches.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While Dr. Welbody mentions she 'had to learn the name of every single bone' in medical school and that it 'was very hard work,' she doesn't expect this from students. She selectively teaches important bones with age-appropriate methods like games. The reference to medical school shows the difference in expectations, not a similarity.
differentiation_notes: Targets overall teaching approach across entire text - differs from reference by analyzing pedagogical strategy across whole passage vs single game purpose. Requires synthesizing evidence from multiple paragraphs about terminology introduction.

specificity_check: all describe methods for presenting medical information to students

question: Dr. Welbody describes her previous visit when students were in first grade. What does this information help you understand about the text's purpose?
option_1: The text is designed to build on prior knowledge while introducing new, more advanced body system information
option_2: The text wants to remind students that they should have already learned all this information two years ago

This shows progressive, developmental learning appropriate for older students.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Dr. Welbody doesn't suggest students should already know thisshe says she's here to teach them 'more,' indicating new content. She compliments their growth ('You have grown so much!') rather than criticizing lack of knowledge. The tone is encouraging and forward-looking, not remedial. Review the opening paragraph's positive framing.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The text explicitly introduces new information. In first grade, she taught about eating healthy; now she's teaching about three body systems with specific bone names and structures. The word 'more' in 'teach you more about your body' signals additional, not repeated, content. Compare what was taught before versus now.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While Dr. Welbody mentions physical growth ('You have grown so much!'), this is a brief greeting, not the text's purpose. option_1: To show that learning bone names requires dedication and that students should appreciate simplified lessons

option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The opposite is trueDr. Welbody is teaching students medical information precisely because it IS useful. option_1: Dr. Welbody cares about students' long-term health and wants them to understand how their bodies function

question: If Dr. Welbody's computer pictures showed bones labeled only with medical terms like 'cranium' and 'sternum' without showing common names like 'skull' and 'breastbone,' how would this change the lesson for students?
option_1: Students would learn the information faster because they would only need to memorize one name per bone
option_2: Students would find the lesson more challenging because they could not connect new terms to familiar concepts
option_3: Students would remember the bones better because medical terms sound more professional and important
option_4: Students would become confused about which bones Dr. Welbody was teaching during the Simon Says game
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While students would learn fewer total terms, learning would likely be slower, not faster. Medical terms without familiar anchors (knowing 'skull' helps learn 'cranium') are harder to grasp and remember. Research on learning shows connecting new knowledge to existing knowledge aids memory. One term doesn't automatically mean easier learning when that term is unfamiliar.
option_2_explanation: Correct! Throughout the text, Dr. Welbody uses a teaching strategy of pairing familiar terms with medical ones: 'your skull...Doctors also call the skull the cranium.' This scaffolding helps students connect what they already know (everyday words) to new vocabulary (medical terms). Without this bridge, students would struggle to visualize and understand what abstract medical terms refer to. The pictures showing only medical terms would lose this crucial connection point.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Professional-sounding terms don't automatically improve memorymeaningful connections do. Third graders are more likely to remember information they can relate to their experiences. When Dr. Welbody says 'tap on your chest, you can feel your breastbone,' the familiar term 'breastbone' helps them connect the physical sensation to the concept. 'Sternum' alone lacks this experiential anchor.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Dr. Welbody could still use medical terms during Simon Saysthe issue isn't game clarity but initial learning. The game happens after the lesson when students already know the terms. The real problem would occur during the teaching phase when students first encounter bones. The game confusion would be a symptom of earlier learning difficulties, not the primary issue.

passage_text:
The Skeletal System
    
    
        Hello! My name is Dr. Welbody. Some of you may remember me from when you were in first grade. I came to your school to teach you about your body. I told you to eat healthy food so you would grow big and strong. It looks like you listened! You have grown so much since then!
Today I am here to teach you more about your body and how it works. We will learn about three important systems. These are the skeletal system, the muscular system, and the nervous system. Each system has a special job to help your body work.

---

Let's start with the skeletal system. The skeletal system is made up of all the bones in your body. These bones give your body its shape. I have pictures on my computer to show you. You have more than 200 bones in your body! When I went to medical school, I had to learn the name of every single bone. That was very hard work!
Let's begin at the top with your skull. Doctors also call the skull the cranium. Your skull has a very important job. It protects your brain, which is a soft organ inside your head. You might think your skull is one big bone, but it's not! Your skull is actually made of 22 different bones that fit together.

---

Now rub the back of your neck. Can you feel the bone there? That is part of your spine. Your spine is made of more than thirty small bones stacked on top of each other. Each small bone is called a vertebra. All these bones together protect your spinal cord, which sends messages to your brain.
If you tap on your chest, you can feel your breastbone. The medical name for this bone is the sternum. If you tap to the left or right, you might feel your ribs. Your ribs protect important organs like your heart and lungs. The ribs look like a cage around these organs. Behind your ribs are two bones shaped like a triangle. These are your shoulder blade bones. The medical name for shoulder blade is scapula.

---

The pelvis is the group of bones at your hips. In your lower leg, you have two important bones. The tibia is the bigger bone, and the fibula is the smaller one next to it.
Now let's play Simon Says to practice these bone names! When you take a deep breath, watch how your rib cage can expand to make room for air. Your skeletal system works with your muscular system and nervous system to help you move and stay healthy. Are you ready to play?
Simon says, tap your skull! Simon says, now tap your cranium! Did I trick you? They are the same bone! Simon says, bend over and touch your tibia. Simon says, take a deep breath and feel your ribs expand. Now touch your scapula! Wait - I didn't say Simon says!
question: The text mentions that Dr. Welbody has pictures on her computer to show students. Based on everything Dr. Welbody teaches, what would be most important for these pictures to include to support her lesson goals?
option_1: Labels showing where each bone is located in the body and what organs or body parts it protects
option_2: Information about how much each individual bone weighs and what material bones are made from
option_3: Comparisons showing how human bones are different from animal bones in size and structure
option_4: Historical facts about when doctors first discovered each bone and named it with medical terms
option_1_explanation: Correct! Throughout the lesson, Dr. Welbody emphasizes two key concepts: location ('your skull,' 'at the back of your neck,' 'in your lower leg') and protective function ('protects your brain,' 'protect your spinal cord,' 'protect important organs like your heart and lungs'). Pictures showing location and protection would directly support these core teaching goals. Her entire lesson structure focuses on where bones are and what they protect.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Dr. Welbody never discusses bone weight or composition. Her lesson focuses on location, names, and protective functions. While bone material might be interesting, it doesn't align with her stated teaching objectives about the skeletal system's structure and role. Review what concepts she actually emphasizes throughout the text.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Dr. Welbody teaches exclusively about human anatomy without any animal comparisons. Her goal is helping students understand their own bodies, not comparative anatomy. While such comparisons could be educational, they don't match her lesson's focus on personal body awareness. Reread to see if animals are mentioned anywhere.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The text contains no historical information about bone discovery or naming. Dr. Welbody focuses on present-day anatomy and function, not history of medicine. She mentions learning names in medical school but not who created those names or when. Her lesson is functional and practical, not historical. Check whether history appears in any paragraph.
differentiation_notes: Targets what visual features would support lesson goals based on whole-text analysis - differs from reference by analyzing visual support needs vs single game purpose. Requires synthesizing main lesson themes across all paragraphs.
homogeneity_check: all choices are types of information pictures could show
specificity_check: all describe potential content for anatomical illustrations
length_check: A: 16 words, B: 15 words, C: 14 words, D: 15 words - balanced within 13%
semantic_distance_check: each suggests different visual content: location/function, weight/composition, comparative anatomy, historical context
single_correct_check: only A is defensible based on consistent emphasis on location and protection throughout
diversity_check: targets analysis of visual support for whole lesson - completely different from reference about single game purpose

question: Dr. Welbody has students perform actions like rubbing their neck and tapping their chest while she explains different bones. Based on the text, why would these actions combined with pictures be more effective than just showing pictures alone?
option_1: The actions help students stay awake and pay attention during a long presentation about anatomy
option_2: The actions let students verify that the picture information is accurate by checking their own bodies
option_3: The actions allow students to physically locate and feel bones, making abstract pictures personally meaningful
option_4: The actions give students exercise while learning so they can practice using their muscular system
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While movement might maintain attention, that's not Dr. Welbody's stated purpose. She specifically directs students to feel specific bones: 'Can you feel the bone there?' This targeted approach is about learning bone locations, not general attention management. Attention is a side benefit, not the main goal. Focus on the educational objectives of each action.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. The text doesn't suggest students are verifying picture accuracythey're learning to locate bones they cannot see. The pictures show internal structures; the touching helps students connect those images to their own bodies. It's about making personal connections, not fact-checking. Dr. Welbody presents information as established facts, not theories to verify.
option_3_explanation: Correct! The text demonstrates this combination: Dr. Welbody shows pictures ('I have pictures on my computer to show you') AND has students touch bones ('rub the back of your neck. Can you feel the bone there?'). Pictures show what bones look like and where they are, but touching lets students experience their own skeletal structure. This transforms pictures from external information into personal, embodied knowledge. The text explicitly connects internal images to physical sensation.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While the text mentions that 'your skeletal system works with your muscular system,' the touching activities aren't designed as muscular exercise. The movements are minimal and focused on sensation ('tap,' 'rub'), not physical conditioning. The goal is skeletal awareness, not muscle development. Review the purpose statements Dr. Welbody provides for each action.

question: Based on how Dr. Welbody structures her lesson from beginning to end, what does the progression from simple activities to the Simon Says game demonstrate about effective teaching?
option_1: Effective teaching starts with difficult concepts and gradually moves toward easier review activities
option_2: Effective teaching builds understanding through steps before asking students to apply knowledge independently
option_3: Effective teaching focuses on testing what students know rather than introducing new information

option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Dr. Welbody's lesson moves from easier to harder, not the reverse. option_2_explanation: Correct! The lesson follows a clear progression: First, Dr. Welbody teaches bone names and locations with guided touching ('Can you feel the bone there?'). passage_text:
All About Bones
    
    
        Last time, we learned the names of some bones in the body. Today, let's learn more about bones! This is a human leg bone called the fibula. The fibula is one of the bones in your leg.

The outside part of a bone is very hard. It is made of the same stuff as a seashell you might find at the beach. This stuff is called calcium. Do you like milk? Milk and other dairy foods like cheese have lots of calcium in them. They are very good for your bones. One way to take care of your bones is to eat healthy foods with dairy products. Exercise is also great for your bones.

---

If you could look inside a bone, you would see something called bone marrow. Since you can't see inside this bone, I'll show you a picture. This picture shows bone marrow cells. You may already know about cells. If you look at things with a strong microscope, you can see that many things are made of tiny cells. Your skin is made of cells. Your bones are made of cells too.

Here you can see some bone marrow cells. There are millions of cells like these inside your bones. The bone marrow cells have a very important job. They work like little factories. They make red blood cells. Then, the red blood cells carry oxygen all around your body.

---

As you get older and taller, your bones grow with you. Bones are very strong. They can hold up a lot of weight. But if we put too much pressure on them, or if the pressure comes from the wrong way, bones can break.
This next picture shows a broken bone. This is a special kind of picture called an x-ray. X-rays help us see inside your body. Your bones are hard, so they show up well in x-ray pictures. The soft tissue around your bones is not as hard. That is why doctors like x-rays. We can take pictures of the inside of your body. We can use x-rays to find out if any bones are broken.

---

Have any of you ever broken a bone? I fix lots of broken bones each year. First, I take x-rays to see if the bone is really broken. If the x-rays show that a bone is broken, then I set the bone. That means I put the bone pieces back in the right place. Once the bones are in the right place, I put on a cast.
One amazing thing about bones is that they can heal themselves. Once a broken bone has been set, it grows back just like it was before. Here's a boy I helped last summer. He broke one of the bones in his arm. I put the cast on to hold the bones in the right place so they would heal. He had to cope with wearing the cast for two months while the bones healed. Then, I cut the cast off for him. He's just fine now. His bone has healed and his arm is as good as new.
question: Based on paragraph 2, what does the word 'stuff' refer to when the author says bones are made of the same stuff as seashells?
option_1: a type of bone marrow
option_2: a mineral called calcium
option_3: red blood cells
option_4: dairy products like milk
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While bone marrow is discussed in the passage, the text explicitly states that the hard outside part of bones is made of calcium, not bone marrow. The passage says 'This stuff is called calcium,' referring to what bones and seashells have in common.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The passage states 'It is made of the same stuff as a seashell you might find at the beach. This stuff is called calcium.' The word 'stuff' in this context refers to calcium, the mineral that makes both bones and seashells hard. Use context clues from surrounding sentences to determine word meanings.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Red blood cells are made BY bone marrow cells, but they are not what makes up the hard outside part of bones. The text clearly identifies calcium as the 'stuff' that bones and seashells share, not red blood cells.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While the passage mentions that dairy products CONTAIN calcium, the 'stuff' being discussed is calcium itself, not the dairy foods. The passage says calcium is what bones are made of, and dairy foods are simply a source of this mineral.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 2's discussion of calcium composition - differs from reference which asks about 'cope' in paragraph 4. Uses 'Based on...' stem and requires understanding of pronoun reference rather than emotion-related vocabulary.
homogeneity_check: all choices are substances/materials (bone marrow, calcium, blood cells, dairy products)
specificity_check: all at concrete noun level naming specific materials
length_check: A=5 words, B=4 words, C=3 words, D=4 words - balanced within acceptable range
semantic_distance_check: no overlapping meanings - each represents distinct material concept
single_correct_check: only B is defensible based on explicit text statement 'This stuff is called calcium'
diversity_check: targets paragraph 2 calcium explanation - completely different from reference's paragraph 4 emotional vocabulary question

question: According to the passage, what does 'set the bone' mean when describing what doctors do?
option_1: take x-ray pictures of the bone
option_2: put the bone pieces in the correct position
option_3: remove the cast from the healed bone
option_4: wait for the bone to grow back together
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Taking x-rays happens BEFORE setting the bone. The passage states 'First, I take x-rays to see if the bone is really broken. If the x-rays show that a bone is broken, then I set the bone.' X-rays help diagnose, but setting is a different action.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The passage directly defines this phrase: 'That means I put the bone pieces back in the right place.' When you encounter unfamiliar medical terms, look for explanatory phrases that follow them. The author provides a clear definition right after introducing the term 'set the bone.'
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Removing the cast happens AFTER the bone has healed, which is weeks or months after setting the bone. The passage explains that setting happens early in treatment, while cast removal is the final step: 'Then, I cut the cast off for him.'
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Waiting for healing occurs after the bone is set. The passage explains the sequence: first the bone is set (put in the right place), then the cast is applied, then the patient waits for healing. Setting is an active step the doctor takes, not a waiting period.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 4's medical procedure terminology - differs from reference which asks about emotional vocabulary 'cope'. Uses 'According to...' stem and focuses on technical/procedural language rather than emotional states.

question: What does the word 'tissue' mean in paragraph 3 when the author says 'The soft tissue around your bones is not as hard'?
option_1: special x-ray pictures
option_2: body material like muscles and skin
option_3: broken bone pieces
option_4: hard calcium structures
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. X-ray pictures are mentioned in the same section, but they are what doctors USE to see inside the body. Tissue refers to actual body parts, not the pictures. The passage contrasts hard bones with soft tissue, showing they are different types of body materials.
option_2_explanation: Correct! From context, we can infer that tissue means body material. The passage contrasts 'hard' bones with 'soft tissue around your bones,' indicating tissue is the body material surrounding bones - things like muscles, organs, and skin. Use comparison context clues (hard vs. soft) to understand domain-specific science terms.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Broken bone pieces are discussed in a different part of the passage about injuries. In this sentence, tissue refers to the soft body material around bones that doesn't show up as clearly in x-rays because it's not as hard as bones are.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. This is the opposite of what tissue means in this context. The passage specifically states that tissue is 'not as hard' as bones, and contrasts soft tissue with the hard calcium structures of bones. Tissue is the soft material, not hard structures.

---

If you could look inside a bone, you would see something called bone marrow. Since you can't see inside this bone, I'll show you a picture. This picture shows bone marrow cells. You may already know about cells. If you look at things with a strong microscope, you can see that many things are made of tiny cells. Your skin is made of cells. Your bones are made of cells too.

Here you can see some bone marrow cells. There are millions of cells like these inside your bones. The bone marrow cells have a very important job. They work like little factories. They make red blood cells. Then, the red blood cells carry oxygen all around your body.

---

As you get older and taller, your bones grow with you. Bones are very strong. They can hold up a lot of weight. But if we put too much pressure on them, or if the pressure comes from the wrong way, bones can break.
This next picture shows a broken bone. This is a special kind of picture called an x-ray. X-rays help us see inside your body. Your bones are hard, so they show up well in x-ray pictures. The soft tissue around your bones is not as hard. That is why doctors like x-rays. We can take pictures of the inside of your body. We can use x-rays to find out if any bones are broken.

---

Have any of you ever broken a bone? I fix lots of broken bones each year. First, I take x-rays to see if the bone is really broken. If the x-rays show that a bone is broken, then I set the bone. That means I put the bone pieces back in the right place. Once the bones are in the right place, I put on a cast.
One amazing thing about bones is that they can heal themselves. Once a broken bone has been set, it grows back just like it was before. Here's a boy I helped last summer. He broke one of the bones in his arm. I put the cast on to hold the bones in the right place so they would heal. He had to cope with wearing the cast for two months while the bones healed. Then, I cut the cast off for him. He's just fine now. His bone has healed and his arm is as good as new.
question: In paragraph 2, what does the phrase 'work like little factories' tell you about bone marrow cells?
option_1: They are very small in size.
option_2: They can be seen with microscopes.
option_3: They produce something important.
option_4: They are found inside bones.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While bone marrow cells ARE small, the phrase 'work like little factories' focuses on what they DO, not their size. The word 'little' in 'little factories' refers to the factory comparison, not specifically to the cells' size. The phrase emphasizes their production function.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Though the passage does mention microscopes earlier, the factory comparison is about the cells' function, not how we observe them. When authors compare things to factories, they're highlighting that something is being manufactured or produced, not discussing observation methods.
option_3_explanation: Correct! The factory comparison emphasizes that bone marrow cells MAKE or PRODUCE something. The very next sentence confirms this: 'They make red blood cells.' When authors use similes like 'work like factories,' they're highlighting the production or manufacturing function. This is a key reading strategy for understanding figurative language.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While the passage does state that bone marrow cells are inside bones, that's not what the factory comparison is emphasizing. The phrase 'work like factories' focuses on their JOB or FUNCTION (making things), not their location. Location and function are different aspects of information.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 2's factory simile about bone marrow cell function - differs from reference which asks about the same simile but as an RI.3.1 question testing explicit text reference. This variant requires DOK 2 interpretation of what the metaphor emphasizes (production) rather than what it states (the cells make blood cells).
homogeneity_check: all choices are characteristics or functions of bone marrow cells
specificity_check: all at descriptive phrase level about cell properties
length_check: A=5 words, B=5 words, C=4 words, D=4 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each describes different aspect: size, observation, function, location
single_correct_check: only C is defensible as the emphasis of the factory metaphor based on context
diversity_check: targets paragraph 2 figurative language interpretation - different from all previous variants and from reference's paragraph 4 focus. Requires inferring metaphor's emphasis rather than explicit statement.
