specificity_check: all describe outcomes that could follow from events
length_check: A=12 words, B=11 words, C=12 words, D=10 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each describes different potential outcome (followers leaving, pirates learning, transformations, divine protection)
single_correct_check: only C identifies the actual stated consequences of Bacchus's magic
diversity_check: targets paragraph 6 analyzing consequential results of magic use - different temporal direction and text location from reference asking about preceding event

passage_text:
Cupid and Psyche, Part I
    
    
        Once there was a king who had three daughters. All three were pretty, but the youngest was named Psyche. She was so beautiful that no words could tell how lovely she was. People started to say she was more beautiful than Venus, the goddess of love and beauty.
Venus heard what people were saying about Psyche. She became very angry and jealous. How could people think a regular girl was prettier than a goddess? Venus decided this had to stop right away!
Venus went to find her son, Cupid. "My son," she said, "you must punish that girl! Take your bow and arrow and shoot her. Make her fall in love with the ugliest man on Earth." Cupid always listened to his mother, so he agreed to do his mother's bidding.

---

Cupid took his bow and arrow and flew down to Earth. He found Psyche and took aim at her. But at the last second, his finger slipped on the arrow. Instead of shooting Psyche, he accidentally made the arrow prick his own finger. The magic arrow made Cupid fall in love with Psyche right away!
Now Cupid had a big problem. He loved Psyche, but he could not let his mother know. So he came up with a secret plan. He sent a message to Psyche's family. The message said that the gods had picked a husband for Psyche. She had to climb to the top of a mountain to meet him. The message also said her husband would be a terrible monster, not a man.
Psyche was scared, but she was also brave. She climbed up the mountain as the message told her to do. Halfway up the mountain, a warm wind lifted her up. Suddenly, she found herself in a magnificent palace with beautiful fountains and gardens everywhere.

---

At first, Psyche was all alone in the palace. When night came, she lay down on a soft bed. During the dark night, Cupid came to visit her. He told her he was the husband the gods had chosen for her. Cupid stayed with her all night and was very kind to her. But he always left before the sun came up.
Night after night, Cupid came to see Psyche. He only came when it was dark, and he always left before morning. Psyche only knew him in the darkness, but she accepted him as her husband. One night, Psyche became very curious. She asked her husband why he only came at night when she could not see him.
"Why do you want to see me?" Cupid asked. "What does it matter how I look? I love you and treat you well. All I ask is that you love me back."

---

Psyche understood what her husband said. But she was still curious about what he looked like. Was he really a monster? She felt she had to find out the truth.
One night, Psyche waited until her husband fell asleep. Then she quietly got up and lit a small lamp. She carried the lamp over to the bed and held it up high. What she saw was not a monster at all! Instead, she saw the lovely face of Cupid himself. Her hand shook with surprise and joy. A drop of hot oil fell from the lamp onto Cupid's shoulder and woke him up.
Cupid looked up at Psyche with sad eyes. "I only asked you to trust me," he said. "But now I see that you do not trust me. When trust is gone, love must depart." Then Cupid flew away into the night. The beautiful palace disappeared, and Psyche was left all alone.
question: According to the passage, what happens immediately after Cupid's finger slips on the arrow?
option_1: Cupid tells Venus about his mistake with the arrow.
option_2: Cupid falls in love with Psyche because of the magic.
option_3: Cupid flies down to Earth to find Psyche again.
option_4: Cupid decides to tell Psyche the truth about himself.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. The text does not say Cupid tells Venus about the accident. In fact, the passage states 'he could not let his mother know,' showing he kept the mistake secret from Venus.
option_2_explanation: This is correct. The text clearly states: 'The magic arrow made Cupid fall in love with Psyche right away!' This happened immediately after he pricked his own finger instead of shooting Psyche.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. Cupid was already on Earth when the accident happened. The passage says 'He found Psyche and took aim at her' before his finger slipped, so he didn't need to fly down again.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. Cupid never tells Psyche the truth about who he is. In fact, he creates a secret plan and only visits her in darkness so she cannot see him.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 4 about the immediate consequence of Cupid's accident - differs from reference which asks about sequencing multiple events using an outline format
homogeneity_check: all choices are immediate actions or consequences
specificity_check: all describe specific story events with similar detail
length_check: A:10 words, B:10 words, C:10 words, D:10 words - perfectly balanced
semantic_distance_check: each choice describes distinctly different actions without overlap
single_correct_check: only B is supported by text evidence about the magic arrow's effect
diversity_check: targets paragraph 4 single-event consequence - completely different from reference outline-based sequencing question

question: Based on paragraph 6, why does Psyche climb up the mountain?
option_1: She wants to explore the beautiful palace and gardens.
option_2: She is searching for Cupid who flew away from her.
option_3: She is following instructions from a message about her husband.
option_4: She needs to escape from Venus who is angry at her.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. Psyche did not know about the palace before climbing the mountain. The text shows she only discovered the palace after the wind lifted her: 'she found herself in a magnificent palace.'
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. Cupid flies away at the end of the story, not at this point. When Psyche climbs the mountain, she has not yet met Cupid or seen him leave.
option_3_explanation: This is correct. The passage states: 'The message said that the gods had picked a husband for Psyche. She had to climb to the top of a mountain to meet him.' Psyche is obeying the instructions in the message Cupid sent.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. While Venus is angry earlier in the story, the text does not say Psyche climbs the mountain to escape. The passage clearly shows she climbs because the message told her to meet her husband there.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 6 motivation for single action - differs from reference which sequences multiple plot events in outline form
homogeneity_check: all choices are reasons or motivations for climbing

question: How does the author show that Psyche arrives at an unexpected place?
option_1: By describing how scared Psyche felt climbing the mountain.
option_2: By explaining that a warm wind suddenly lifted her up.
option_3: By telling readers that Cupid sent her a secret message.
option_4: By showing that Psyche had to be brave and strong.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. While the text mentions Psyche was scared, this describes her feelings before climbing, not how the author shows the arrival was unexpected. Fear doesn't demonstrate unexpected arrival.
option_2_explanation: This is correct. The passage uses 'Suddenly' and describes how 'a warm wind lifted her up' and she unexpectedly 'found herself in a magnificent palace.' The sudden wind and abrupt change in location show the arrival was unexpected.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. The secret message tells Psyche to climb the mountain, but it doesn't show that her arrival at the palace was unexpected. The message is about why she climbs, not about the surprising way she arrives.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. Psyche being brave describes her character trait before climbing, not how the author demonstrates the unexpected nature of her arrival at the palace. Bravery is about her decision to climb, not the surprising arrival.

question: Which detail from the story best shows that Cupid wants to keep his identity hidden?
option_1: He sends a message saying her husband will be a monster.
option_2: He uses his bow and arrow to make people fall in love.
option_3: He agrees to follow his mother's orders to punish Psyche.
option_4: He visits Psyche at night and leaves before the sun comes up.
option_1_explanation: This detail shows part of Cupid's deception, but it is not the best evidence of hiding his identity. The message creates false expectations but doesn't directly show his pattern of concealment during their interactions.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. Using a bow and arrow describes Cupid's magical ability, not his efforts to hide his identity from Psyche. This detail is about his powers as a god, not about secrecy.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. Agreeing to punish Psyche happens before Cupid falls in love with her and before he needs to hide his identity. This detail is about his obedience to Venus, not about concealing who he is.
option_4_explanation: This is correct. The text emphasizes this pattern repeatedly: 'He only came when it was dark, and he always left before morning.' This deliberate pattern of visiting only in darkness directly demonstrates his effort to prevent Psyche from seeing and identifying him.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraphs 7-8 evidence of sustained concealment behavior - differs from reference which uses outline to sequence disconnected plot events

question: What lesson does this myth teach about relationships?
option_1: People should always listen to their parents' advice.
option_2: Beautiful palaces can make people very happy.
option_3: Breaking someone's trust can destroy love between people.
option_4: Jealousy makes people want to hurt others badly.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. While Cupid initially listens to his mother, the story shows problems arise from this obedience. The main lesson is not about following parents but about trust. Cupid's obedience to Venus actually creates the central conflict.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. The palace disappears at the end, showing that material things like beautiful places are not what matters. The story emphasizes that trust and love are more important than physical surroundings or possessions.
option_3_explanation: This is correct. The entire story builds to this lesson. Cupid says 'I only asked you to trust me' and 'When trust is gone, love must depart.' Psyche's breaking of trust by lighting the lamp causes Cupid to leave and their relationship to end.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. While jealousy is shown through Venus's actions early in the story, it is not the main lesson. The central focus is on Psyche and Cupid's relationship and what happens when trust is broken between them.
differentiation_notes: Targets overall moral/theme of the complete narrative - differs from reference which asks about story purpose, focusing on different aspect of RL.3.2

question: The story teaches readers that
option_1: keeping secrets from family members is always wrong
option_2: curiosity can lead people to make harmful choices
option_3: being beautiful causes many problems for people
option_4: listening to gods will bring rewards to people
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. The story is not about keeping secrets from family being wrong. Cupid keeps his identity secret from Psyche (not family), and the problem is not the secrecy itself but Psyche's inability to trust despite being treated well.
option_2_explanation: This is correct. The story shows how Psyche's curiosity leads her to light the lamp despite Cupid's request. This choice harms both of them - she loses her husband, the palace disappears, and Cupid is burned and heartbroken. Her curiosity directly causes these negative consequences.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. While Psyche's beauty triggers Venus's jealousy initially, the main lesson is not about beauty causing problems. The central message focuses on what happens later between Psyche and Cupid when trust is broken.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. Following the gods' instructions does not bring rewards in this story. Psyche follows the message to climb the mountain, but ultimately loses everything when she cannot control her curiosity and breaks Cupid's trust.
differentiation_notes: Targets the consequence-based moral about curiosity and choices - differs from reference which asks about story purpose in broader terms

passage_text:
Cupid and Psyche, Part I
    
    
        Once there was a king who had three daughters. All three were pretty, but the youngest was named Psyche. She was so beautiful that no words could tell how lovely she was. People started to say she was more beautiful than Venus, the goddess of love and beauty.
Venus heard what people were saying about Psyche. She became very angry and jealous. How could people think a regular girl was prettier than a goddess? Venus decided this had to stop right away!
Venus went to find her son, Cupid. "My son," she said, "you must punish that girl! Take your bow and arrow and shoot her. Make her fall in love with the ugliest man on Earth." Cupid always listened to his mother, so he agreed to do his mother's bidding.

---

Cupid took his bow and arrow and flew down to Earth. He found Psyche and took aim at her. But at the last second, his finger slipped on the arrow. Instead of shooting Psyche, he accidentally made the arrow prick his own finger. The magic arrow made Cupid fall in love with Psyche right away!
Now Cupid had a big problem. He loved Psyche, but he could not let his mother know. So he came up with a secret plan. He sent a message to Psyche's family. The message said that the gods had picked a husband for Psyche. She had to climb to the top of a mountain to meet him. The message also said her husband would be a terrible monster, not a man.
Psyche was scared, but she was also brave. She climbed up the mountain as the message told her to do. Halfway up the mountain, a warm wind lifted her up. Suddenly, she found herself in a magnificent palace with beautiful fountains and gardens everywhere.

---

At first, Psyche was all alone in the palace. When night came, she lay down on a soft bed. During the dark night, Cupid came to visit her. He told her he was the husband the gods had chosen for her. Cupid stayed with her all night and was very kind to her. But he always left before the sun came up.
Night after night, Cupid came to see Psyche. He only came when it was dark, and he always left before morning. Psyche only knew him in the darkness, but she accepted him as her husband. One night, Psyche became very curious. She asked her husband why he only came at night when she could not see him.
"Why do you want to see me?" Cupid asked. "What does it matter how I look? I love you and treat you well. All I ask is that you love me back."

---

Psyche understood what her husband said. But she was still curious about what he looked like. Was he really a monster? She felt she had to find out the truth.
One night, Psyche waited until her husband fell asleep. Then she quietly got up and lit a small lamp. She carried the lamp over to the bed and held it up high. What she saw was not a monster at all! Instead, she saw the lovely face of Cupid himself. Her hand shook with surprise and joy. A drop of hot oil fell from the lamp onto Cupid's shoulder and woke him up.
Cupid looked up at Psyche with sad eyes. "I only asked you to trust me," he said. "But now I see that you do not trust me. When trust is gone, love must depart." Then Cupid flew away into the night. The beautiful palace disappeared, and Psyche was left all alone.
question: Based on key details throughout the story, what central message does the author convey?
option_1: Physical appearance matters less than how people treat each other.
option_2: Children should obey their parents even when it seems unfair.
option_3: Magical powers can solve problems better than honest communication.
option_4: Wealthy surroundings help people feel more secure in relationships.
option_1_explanation: This is correct. The story emphasizes this through multiple details: Cupid says 'What does it matter how I look? I love you and treat you well.' He treats Psyche kindly regardless of whether she can see him, and she accepts him based on his treatment, not his appearance. The tragedy occurs when she cannot accept this message.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. While Cupid initially obeys Venus, this obedience creates problems rather than serving as the story's message. The story focuses on the relationship between Cupid and Psyche, not on parent-child obedience as a central theme.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. Magic actually causes problems in the story - the magic arrow creates Cupid's dilemma, and magical concealment prevents honest communication. The story suggests that honest communication and trust would have been better than magical solutions.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The palace disappears at the story's end, showing that wealth and surroundings do not create security. The text emphasizes that trust and love create security in relationships, not material possessions or beautiful places.
differentiation_notes: Targets character dialogue and multiple story elements to determine theme - differs from reference which asks about overall story purpose using different framing
homogeneity_check: all choices are abstract life lessons or messages
specificity_check: all express thematic principles at similar complexity
length_check: A:9 words, B:9 words, C:8 words, D:8 words - within 10% range
semantic_distance_check: each message addresses different thematic concept
single_correct_check: only A is supported by Cupid's dialogue and story resolution
diversity_check: targets theme through character dialogue analysis - different from reference which asks about story purpose

question: Which message is most clearly shown through Cupid's words and Psyche's actions?
option_1: Goddesses are more powerful than regular humans can ever be.
option_2: People who live in palaces have easier lives than others.
option_3: Love requires accepting people without demanding to know everything.
option_4: Following mysterious messages always leads to discovering wonderful places.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. While Venus is a goddess and has power, the story's message is not about goddess power versus human power. The focus is on the personal relationship between Cupid and Psyche and what causes it to fail.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. The palace setting is not the focus of the story's message. In fact, Psyche's life in the palace becomes difficult because of the mystery, and she loses the palace when she breaks trust, showing material comfort is not the message.
option_3_explanation: This is correct. Cupid explicitly asks Psyche to love him without seeing him: 'All I ask is that you love me back.' He emphasizes that appearance doesn't matter if treatment is good. When Psyche cannot accept this and demands to see him, their love ends, proving this is the central message.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. While following the message leads Psyche to a palace, this is not the story's main message. The message is about what happens afterward in the relationship, not about the benefits of following mysterious instructions.

option_3: beautiful palaces are the best gifts for young women
option_4: trust is the most important part of any relationship

option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. The story does not show Venus thinking about sons protecting mothers. Instead, she uses her son Cupid to carry out her plan of revenge against Psyche. Her focus is on maintaining her superior status, not on protection.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. Venus never mentions or creates palaces in the story. Cupid creates the palace as part of his secret plan, not Venus. Venus wants to punish Psyche by making her fall in love with an ugly man, not give her gifts.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. Venus never discusses or demonstrates concern about trust in relationships. Her actions show she is focused on jealousy and revenge, not on building trusting relationships. This is more aligned with Cupid's perspective, not Venus's.

question: Based on her actions in the story, Psyche most likely believes that
option_1: following directions from gods will always lead to happiness
option_2: knowing the truth is more important than keeping promises
option_3: beautiful people deserve to live in fancy palaces
option_4: monsters can sometimes be kind to the people they meet
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. While Psyche does follow the gods' message initially, her final action of lighting the lamp goes against her husband's wishes and leads to unhappiness, not happiness. Her actions show she does not believe following divine direction guarantees happiness.
option_2_explanation: This is correct. Despite promising to accept her husband without seeing him, Psyche's curiosity makes her light the lamp because 'she felt she had to find out the truth.' She breaks the implicit trust to discover the truth about his appearance, showing truth matters more to her than keeping her promise.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. The text describes Psyche as beautiful, but there is no evidence she believes beauty deserves palaces. She accepts the palace but does not claim it is her right because of her beauty. The story does not show her having entitled beliefs.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. While the message says her husband will be a monster, Psyche's husband (Cupid) is kind to her, and she experiences this kindness. However, her actions of lighting the lamp show she doubts he is truly a monster, not that she believes monsters can be kind.

question: What does Psyche's behavior on the mountain reveal about her point of view?
option_1: She thinks that following instructions is more important than her fears.

option_3: She knows that magnificent palaces are always safe places to stay.
option_4: She feels that climbing mountains is an easy task to complete.
option_1_explanation: This is correct. The text states 'Psyche was scared, but she was also brave. She climbed up the mountain as the message told her to do.' Despite her fear, she follows the instructions, revealing that she values obedience and duty over her personal fear.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. While a warm wind does lift her, there is no evidence Psyche interprets this as good luck or has beliefs about warm winds. The wind surprises her suddenly, and her view of it is not described in the text.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. Psyche has not yet seen the palace when she climbs the mountain, so she cannot have knowledge or beliefs about it being safe. She discovers the palace only after the wind lifts her, and the text does not describe her views on palace safety.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The text says Psyche was 'scared,' which suggests she does not find the task easy. Her bravery is emphasized precisely because the task is difficult and frightening, not because she thinks it is easy.

question: The narrator's description of Cupid's reaction suggests that the narrator believes
option_1: people who make mistakes deserve to be punished by others
option_2: keeping secrets from mothers is always the right decision
option_3: breaking trust in a relationship causes genuine sadness and pain
option_4: lighting lamps at night is dangerous for people in palaces
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. The narrator does not present Cupid as deserving punishment. Instead, the narrator describes Cupid with 'sad eyes' and quotes his hurt feelings, creating sympathy for him rather than suggesting he should be punished for his earlier deception.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. The narrator presents Cupid's secret-keeping as creating problems, not as the right decision. The narrator shows that the secrecy leads to Psyche's distrust and their eventual separation, suggesting the narrator sees problems with this choice.
option_3_explanation: This is correct. The narrator describes Cupid looking at Psyche 'with sad eyes' and quotes him saying 'When trust is gone, love must depart.' The narrator's language choice emphasizes the emotional pain and genuine sadness that comes from broken trust, revealing the narrator's perspective.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. While lighting the lamp leads to problems, the narrator presents the danger as breaking trust, not physical danger from lamps. The narrator focuses on the emotional and relational consequences, not on practical safety issues with lighting.

The message said that the gods had picked a husband for Psyche. She had to climb to the top of a mountain to meet him. The message also said her husband would be a terrible monster, not a man.
Psyche was scared, but she was also brave. She climbed up the mountain as the message told her to do. Halfway up the mountain, a warm wind lifted her up. Suddenly, she found herself in a magnificent palace with beautiful fountains and gardens everywhere.

---

At first, Psyche was all alone in the palace. When night came, she lay down on a soft bed. During the dark night, Cupid came to visit her. He told her he was the husband the gods had chosen for her. Cupid stayed with her all night and was very kind to her. But he always left before the sun came up.
Night after night, Cupid came to see Psyche. He only came when it was dark, and he always left before morning. Psyche only knew him in the darkness, but she accepted him as her husband. One night, Psyche became very curious. She asked her husband why he only came at night when she could not see him.
"Why do you want to see me?" Cupid asked. "What does it matter how I look? I love you and treat you well. All I ask is that you love me back."

---

Psyche understood what her husband said. But she was still curious about what he looked like. Was he really a monster? She felt she had to find out the truth.
One night, Psyche waited until her husband fell asleep. Then she quietly got up and lit a small lamp. She carried the lamp over to the bed and held it up high. What she saw was not a monster at all! Instead, she saw the lovely face of Cupid himself. Her hand shook with surprise and joy. A drop of hot oil fell from the lamp onto Cupid's shoulder and woke him up.
Cupid looked up at Psyche with sad eyes. "I only asked you to trust me," he said. "But now I see that you do not trust me. When trust is gone, love must depart." Then Cupid flew away into the night. The beautiful palace disappeared, and Psyche was left all alone.
question: Why does Cupid most likely leave Psyche at the end of the story?
option_1: He discovers that she does not truly love him anymore.
option_2: He realizes that she broke her promise to trust him.
option_3: He becomes angry that she burned him with the hot oil.
option_4: He decides that he must return to obey his mother Venus.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. Cupid does not say Psyche stopped loving him. His sad words focus on trust: 'I only asked you to trust me' and 'you do not trust me.' The issue is broken trust, not lack of love. He leaves because trust is gone, not love.
option_2_explanation: This is correct. Cupid explicitly states: 'I only asked you to trust me. But now I see that you do not trust me. When trust is gone, love must depart.' He had asked her to accept him without seeing him, and she broke this trust by lighting the lamp. This broken promise causes him to leave.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. While the hot oil burns Cupid's shoulder and wakes him, his words show disappointment about broken trust, not anger about being burned. He speaks with 'sad eyes' about trust, not with anger about physical pain. The burn reveals her distrust but is not why he leaves.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. Cupid disobeyed his mother by falling in love with Psyche instead of punishing her, and there is no evidence he decides to return to Venus at the end. His words focus entirely on Psyche's broken trust, not on obligations to his mother.
differentiation_notes: Targets Cupid's motivation for departure based on his dialogue in paragraph 10 - differs from reference which asks about Cupid's beliefs about relationships generally
homogeneity_check: all choices are reasons or motivations for leaving
specificity_check: all provide specific causal explanations for the action
length_check: A:10 words, B:10 words, C:10 words, D:10 words - perfectly balanced
semantic_distance_check: each reason represents distinctly different motivation
single_correct_check: only B matches Cupid's explicit statement about trust being gone
diversity_check: targets Cupid's specific departure motivation - completely different from reference about general beliefs about trust

question: How do Cupid's actions throughout the story help explain why he feels disappointed at the end?
option_1: He created a comfortable life for Psyche but she wanted more information.
option_2: He followed his mother's orders carefully but Psyche disobeyed the gods.
option_3: He gave Psyche beautiful fountains and gardens but she preferred darkness.
option_4: He tried to punish Psyche with the arrow but accidentally hurt himself instead.
option_1_explanation: This is correct. Throughout the story, Cupid provides Psyche with a magnificent palace, treats her kindly, and visits her nightly. Despite this comfortable life and good treatment, Psyche cannot accept not knowing what he looks like. His disappointment stems from giving her everything except visibility, yet that one thing matters more to her than his treatment and the life he provided.
option_2_explanation: This is incorrect. Cupid actually disobeys his mother by falling in love with Psyche instead of punishing her. His disappointment is not about following orders versus disobedience to gods. It is about Psyche's inability to trust him personally in their relationship.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. Psyche does not prefer darkness - she lights a lamp specifically to see in the darkness. Cupid's disappointment is not about her preferring darkness but about her inability to trust him without seeing him. The beautiful surroundings are part of what he provided, not something she rejected.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. The accidental arrow prick happens early and causes Cupid to fall in love, which is not related to his disappointment at the end. His end disappointment is about Psyche breaking trust by lighting the lamp, not about his earlier accident with the arrow.

question: What do Psyche's actions in paragraph 10 reveal about how she has changed since arriving at the palace?
option_1: She has become more trusting of the people around her.
option_2: She has grown more confident in making her own decisions.
option_3: She has started to appreciate beautiful palaces and gardens more.
option_4: She has learned to control her curiosity better than before.
option_1_explanation: This is incorrect. Psyche's action of lighting the lamp shows she has become less trusting, not more. She cannot trust her husband's good treatment and must verify his appearance, demonstrating decreased trust rather than increased trust.
option_2_explanation: This is correct. When Psyche first arrives, she passively accepts what happens to her - the wind lifts her, she finds herself in the palace, she accepts her husband in darkness. By paragraph 10, she makes an active decision to light the lamp despite her husband's request, showing she has gained confidence to act on her own judgment even when it contradicts instructions.
option_3_explanation: This is incorrect. Appreciation of palaces is not what paragraph 10 reveals. Her action of lighting the lamp is about wanting to see her husband, not about valuing or appreciating the physical surroundings. The palace actually disappears as a consequence of her action.
option_4_explanation: This is incorrect. Psyche's action shows the opposite - she has not controlled her curiosity. The text states 'she was still curious' and 'felt she had to find out the truth,' leading her to light the lamp. This demonstrates her curiosity controlling her, not her controlling it.

passage_text:
Cupid and Psyche, Part II
    
    
        When Cupid left Psyche, she felt very sad. She looked for Cupid everywhere. She walked during the day and night. But she could not find her lost love anywhere. Finally, Psyche went to Venus's temple. She asked the goddess to help her find Cupid. Venus did not want to help. She was still jealous of Psyche's beauty. Venus was confident that she could give Psyche a task that was too hard to finish.
Venus led Psyche to a huge pile of grain. The pile had wheat, millet, barley, and lentils all mixed together. "Sort all the grains into separate stacks by morning," Venus ordered. Then she gave a mean laugh and disappeared. Psyche saw millions of seeds in the pile. She knew she could never finish this job. She sat down and began to cry.

---

Then something amazing happened. Through her tears, Psyche saw one seed moving, then another, and then many more. An army of ants had come to aid her! Each ant carried a seed. Working together, they sorted all the seeds into separate piles. In the morning, Venus was shocked to find the work was done.
"Your next task will be much harder!" Venus said. "Take this box to the underworld and ask Queen Proserpina to send me some of her beauty." Psyche's heart sank. No human had ever gone to the underworld and come back alive. Just then, a mysterious voice spoke to her.

---

"Take a coin for the boatman," the voice said. "If you pay him, he will carry you across the river to the underworld. Take a cake too. Give the cake to the three-headed dog who guards the entrance, and he will let you pass. Most important of all, once Proserpina puts beauty in the box, do not open it!"
Psyche followed the voice's advice. She traveled safely to the underworld. Queen Proserpina gave her the box of beauty for Venus. But Psyche wondered what was inside the box. She lifted the lid and looked inside. A deep sleep came over her right away. She fell to the ground.

---

Luckily, Cupid was watching over her. Even though he was upset with Psyche, he still loved her very much. When he saw her lying on the ground, he felt pity for her. He lifted the sleeping spell and Psyche woke up. "See what happens when you are too curious?" Cupid said with a smile. Psyche smiled back at him.
Psyche brought the box to Venus. Then Cupid went to Jupiter and asked to marry Psyche with the king of the gods' blessing. Jupiter agreed. He let Psyche drink ambrosia, the special drink of the gods. The ambrosia made Psyche immortal like the gods. So Cupid and Psyche were married and lived happily ever after.
question: According to the story, what does Venus do right after she tells Psyche to sort the grains?
option_1: She gives a mean laugh and disappears.
option_2: She watches Psyche cry about the task.
option_3: She brings an army of ants to help.
option_4: She leads Psyche to the underworld.
option_1_explanation: Correct! The text states that after Venus ordered Psyche to sort the grains, 'Then she gave a mean laugh and disappeared.' This shows the sequence of events Venus followed.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. While Psyche does cry, Venus had already disappeared before this happened. The text says Venus disappeared right after giving the order, not that she stayed to watch.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Venus does not bring the ants - they come on their own to help Psyche. Venus is trying to make the task impossible, not easier.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Venus leads Psyche to the underworld later in the story as a second task. The question asks what happens right after the grain-sorting task is given.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 1 Venus dialogue and immediate action - differs from reference which asks about overall story sequence across multiple paragraphs
homogeneity_check: all choices are actions Venus takes in the story
specificity_check: all provide specific actions with similar detail
length_check: A: 8 words, B: 7 words, C: 8 words, D: 7 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each describes distinctly different actions at different story points
single_correct_check: only A matches the immediate sequence described in paragraph 1
diversity_check: targets specific Venus action in paragraph 1 - completely different from reference's multi-event sequencing

option_3: Venus is too busy sorting grains in her temple.

option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Venus doesn't help Psyche become immortal - Jupiter does that at the end. Venus refuses to help because of jealousy, not because of any plan about immortality.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Venus doesn't sort grains herself - she makes Psyche do this as an impossible task. The text shows Venus is free to give tasks, not busy doing them herself.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Venus sends Psyche to the underworld later as a task, but she doesn't go herself. The text explains her refusal is due to jealousy, not because she's busy traveling.

passage_text:
Cupid and Psyche, Part II
    
    
        When Cupid left Psyche, she felt very sad. She looked for Cupid everywhere. She walked during the day and night. But she could not find her lost love anywhere. Finally, Psyche went to Venus's temple. She asked the goddess to help her find Cupid. Venus did not want to help. She was still jealous of Psyche's beauty. Venus was confident that she could give Psyche a task that was too hard to finish.
Venus led Psyche to a huge pile of grain. The pile had wheat, millet, barley, and lentils all mixed together. "Sort all the grains into separate stacks by morning," Venus ordered. Then she gave a mean laugh and disappeared. Psyche saw millions of seeds in the pile. She knew she could never finish this job. She sat down and began to cry.

---

Then something amazing happened. Through her tears, Psyche saw one seed moving, then another, and then many more. An army of ants had come to aid her! Each ant carried a seed. Working together, they sorted all the seeds into separate piles. In the morning, Venus was shocked to find the work was done.
"Your next task will be much harder!" Venus said. "Take this box to the underworld and ask Queen Proserpina to send me some of her beauty." Psyche's heart sank. No human had ever gone to the underworld and come back alive. Just then, a mysterious voice spoke to her.

---

"Take a coin for the boatman," the voice said. "If you pay him, he will carry you across the river to the underworld. Take a cake too. Give the cake to the three-headed dog who guards the entrance, and he will let you pass. Most important of all, once Proserpina puts beauty in the box, do not open it!"
Psyche followed the voice's advice. She traveled safely to the underworld. Queen Proserpina gave her the box of beauty for Venus. But Psyche wondered what was inside the box. She lifted the lid and looked inside. A deep sleep came over her right away. She fell to the ground.

---

Luckily, Cupid was watching over her. Even though he was upset with Psyche, he still loved her very much. When he saw her lying on the ground, he felt pity for her. He lifted the sleeping spell and Psyche woke up. "See what happens when you are too curious?" Cupid said with a smile. Psyche smiled back at him.
Psyche brought the box to Venus. Then Cupid went to Jupiter and asked to marry Psyche with the king of the gods' blessing. Jupiter agreed. He let Psyche drink ambrosia, the special drink of the gods. The ambrosia made Psyche immortal like the gods. So Cupid and Psyche were married and lived happily ever after.
question: What happens right before Psyche travels to the underworld?
option_1: Venus is shocked to find all the grain work is done.
option_2: Psyche hears a mysterious voice give her helpful advice.
option_3: Cupid lifts the sleeping spell and Psyche wakes up.
option_4: Jupiter agrees to let Cupid marry Psyche with his blessing.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Venus being shocked happens earlier in the story, after the grain-sorting task is completed. The question asks what happens right before the underworld journey, which comes later.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The text shows that after Venus gives Psyche the underworld task, 'Just then, a mysterious voice spoke to her' and gave advice about the coin, cake, and not opening the box. Then 'Psyche followed the voice's advice. She traveled safely to the underworld.'
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Cupid lifting the sleeping spell happens after Psyche returns from the underworld and opens the box. This is later in the story, not before her journey.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Jupiter's agreement happens at the very end of the story, after Psyche completes all her tasks and returns from the underworld. This comes much later.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 3 sequence immediately before underworld journey - differs from reference which spans entire story's major events
homogeneity_check: all choices are story events that occur at different points
specificity_check: all describe complete story events with similar detail
length_check: A: 10 words, B: 9 words, C: 9 words, D: 10 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each event occurs at distinctly different story moments (after grains, before underworld, after underworld, at ending)
single_correct_check: only B occurs in the correct sequence position before underworld travel
diversity_check: targets specific sequence point in paragraph 3 - different from reference's broader story sequencing

question: What is the most important message readers should learn from what happens to Psyche in this story?
option_1: Gods always reward people who work hard without complaining.
option_2: Being curious and disobeying warnings can lead to problems.
option_3: Ants are the most helpful creatures when you need assistance.
option_4: Immortal beings should never fall in love with regular humans.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While Psyche does work hard, the story's lesson focuses on her curiosity and disobedience when she opens the box despite being warned not to. Hard work isn't the central message.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The story teaches that curiosity and disobeying warnings cause trouble. Psyche was warned not to open the box, but her curiosity led her to disobey. This caused her to fall into a deep sleep, and Cupid even says 'See what happens when you are too curious?'
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. While ants do help Psyche, the story's main lesson isn't about ants being helpful. The lesson is about the consequences of Psyche's curiosity when she opens the box despite warnings.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The story actually shows the opposite - Cupid and Psyche's love succeeds, and she becomes immortal so they can be together. This isn't presented as a problem to avoid.
differentiation_notes: Targets overall story lesson across all paragraphs - differs from reference which asks about specific dialogue Cupid speaks
homogeneity_check: all choices are potential life lessons or morals
specificity_check: all state complete moral lessons with similar abstraction
length_check: A: 9 words, B: 9 words, C: 10 words, D: 9 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each presents distinctly different moral (work ethic, curiosity consequences, helper importance, love restrictions)
single_correct_check: only B matches the curiosity/disobedience theme emphasized throughout
diversity_check: asks for overall moral rather than specific character dialogue - different approach from reference

question: Based on the tasks Venus gives Psyche, what lesson does the story teach about facing challenges?
option_1: Impossible tasks can be completed with help from others and good advice.
option_2: Jealous people always try to make others fail at everything they do.
option_3: Magic powers are necessary to solve any difficult problem in life.
option_4: Crying is the best way to get someone to come and help you.
option_1_explanation: Correct! The story shows that Psyche completes seemingly impossible tasks (sorting millions of seeds, traveling to the underworld) by receiving help from the ants and following advice from the mysterious voice. This teaches that challenges can be overcome with assistance and guidance.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. While Venus is jealous and does try to make Psyche fail, this describes Venus's behavior rather than teaching a lesson about how to face challenges. The lesson focuses on Psyche's success, not Venus's jealousy.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Psyche doesn't use magic powers - she succeeds through help from others (ants) and following advice (the mysterious voice). The lesson is about accepting help, not about needing magic.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While Psyche does cry and then receives help, the story doesn't teach that crying brings help. The ants and voice come to help because they recognize her need, and she succeeds by following advice, not by crying.
differentiation_notes: Targets lesson from Venus's challenges across paragraphs 1-3 - differs from reference which focuses on Cupid's specific dialogue about curiosity
homogeneity_check: all choices are lessons about facing challenges or problems
specificity_check: all state complete lessons with similar complexity
length_check: A: 11 words, B: 12 words, C: 11 words, D: 12 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each lesson focuses on different aspect (help-seeking, others' motivations, magic solutions, emotional reactions)
single_correct_check: only A reflects the pattern demonstrated through both major tasks
diversity_check: synthesizes lesson from multiple challenge episodes - different from reference's single dialogue focus

question: The story shows that Psyche learns an important lesson. What evidence from multiple parts of the text best supports this lesson?
option_1: Psyche walks day and night searching, then asks Venus for help finding Cupid.
option_2: Psyche opens the box even after being warned not to, which causes her to fall asleep.
option_3: Psyche receives help from ants with the grains and advice from a voice for the underworld.
option_4: Cupid watches over Psyche, lifts the sleeping spell, and then smiles when speaking to her.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. This shows Psyche's determination to find Cupid, but doesn't demonstrate the lesson about curiosity causing problems that Cupid teaches her after she opens the box.
option_2_explanation: Correct! This evidence supports the lesson about curiosity and disobedience. Psyche was explicitly warned 'do not open it,' but her curiosity made her disobey. The consequence (falling asleep) and Cupid's words 'See what happens when you are too curious?' teach this lesson.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. While this shows Psyche receiving help, it doesn't demonstrate the lesson about curiosity that the story teaches. This evidence relates to accepting help, not to the consequences of being too curious.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. This shows Cupid's love and forgiveness, but doesn't provide evidence of the lesson Psyche learns. Cupid's actions show his character, not the lesson about curiosity.
differentiation_notes: Targets evidence for curiosity lesson from paragraphs 3-4 - differs from reference which asks about Cupid's direct statement of the lesson

question: How does the author show that the lesson about curiosity is the central message of the story?
option_1: By having Cupid directly tell Psyche 'See what happens when you are too curious?' after she opens the box.
option_2: By describing how Venus feels jealous of Psyche's beauty throughout the entire story.
option_3: By showing that ants work together to help Psyche sort all the different types of grain.
option_4: By explaining that Jupiter allows Psyche to drink ambrosia and become immortal like the gods.
option_1_explanation: Correct! The author makes curiosity the central message by having Cupid explicitly state it after the box incident. This direct statement, combined with the consequence Psyche faces for her curiosity, emphasizes this as the main lesson readers should learn.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Venus's jealousy motivates her actions but isn't the central message. The author uses Venus to create challenges, but the lesson focuses on Psyche's curiosity, not Venus's jealousy.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The ants helping shows cooperation and assistance, but this isn't the central message. The author uses this to show one challenge being overcome, not to teach the main lesson about curiosity.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Psyche becoming immortal is the happy ending, but it doesn't convey the central message. The lesson about curiosity comes from the box incident, not from the immortality reward.
differentiation_notes: Targets author's craft in conveying lesson through paragraph 4 dialogue - differs from reference which asks students to identify the lesson content

question: Read this sentence from the story: 'Psyche's heart sank.' What does this phrase tell the reader?
option_1: Psyche's heart fell down inside her body.
option_2: Psyche felt suddenly very sad or discouraged.
option_3: Psyche needed to see a doctor about her heart.
option_4: Psyche's heart started beating faster from running.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. This interprets 'heart sank' as literal language, meaning the heart actually moved down. However, hearts don't really sink in the body. This is figurative language describing an emotion, not a physical event.
option_2_explanation: Correct! 'Psyche's heart sank' is nonliteral language meaning she felt suddenly sad, discouraged, or upset. The text uses this phrase when Venus tells her to go to the underworld, showing Psyche's emotional reaction to receiving such a difficult and dangerous task.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. This treats the phrase as literal medical language about heart problems. However, 'heart sank' is figurative language describing how someone feels emotionally, not a description of a medical condition.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. This interprets the phrase as literal language about heart rate. However, 'heart sank' is figurative language for feeling discouraged or sad, not a description of physical heart activity from exercise.
differentiation_notes: Targets nonliteral phrase 'heart sank' from paragraph 2 - differs from reference which focuses on verb usage of 'aid'
homogeneity_check: all choices are interpretations of what the phrase means
specificity_check: all provide complete interpretations with similar detail
length_check: A: 8 words, B: 8 words, C: 9 words, D: 8 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each interpretation differs (literal body movement, figurative emotion, medical issue, physical response)
single_correct_check: only B correctly identifies the figurative meaning
diversity_check: targets different phrase analyzing literal vs. nonliteral - completely different from reference's verb usage question

question: What does the word 'mysterious' mean in the sentence 'Just then, a mysterious voice spoke to her'?
option_1: Very loud and easy to hear clearly.
option_2: Unknown and difficult to explain or identify.
option_3: Friendly and kind to people in trouble.
option_4: Scary and meant to frighten someone badly.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. 'Mysterious' doesn't describe volume or clarity of sound. The word refers to something unknown or unexplained. The voice's volume isn't what makes it mysterious - it's that Psyche doesn't know who is speaking.
option_2_explanation: Correct! 'Mysterious' means unknown, unexplained, or difficult to identify. The voice is mysterious because Psyche doesn't know who is speaking to her or where the voice comes from. The text emphasizes this by calling it a 'mysterious voice' rather than identifying the speaker.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. While the voice does give helpful, kind advice, 'mysterious' doesn't mean friendly or kind. It means unknown or unexplained. The voice is mysterious because its source is unknown, not because of its personality.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. 'Mysterious' doesn't mean scary or frightening. It means unknown or unexplained. Though mysterious things can sometimes be scary, the word itself just means the identity or source is unknown, not that it's meant to frighten.

passage_text:
Cupid and Psyche, Part II
    
    
        When Cupid left Psyche, she felt very sad. She looked for Cupid everywhere. She walked during the day and night. But she could not find her lost love anywhere. Finally, Psyche went to Venus's temple. She asked the goddess to help her find Cupid. Venus did not want to help. She was still jealous of Psyche's beauty. Venus was confident that she could give Psyche a task that was too hard to finish.
Venus led Psyche to a huge pile of grain. The pile had wheat, millet, barley, and lentils all mixed together. "Sort all the grains into separate stacks by morning," Venus ordered. Then she gave a mean laugh and disappeared. Psyche saw millions of seeds in the pile. She knew she could never finish this job. She sat down and began to cry.

---

Then something amazing happened. Through her tears, Psyche saw one seed moving, then another, and then many more. An army of ants had come to aid her! Each ant carried a seed. Working together, they sorted all the seeds into separate piles. In the morning, Venus was shocked to find the work was done.
"Your next task will be much harder!" Venus said. "Take this box to the underworld and ask Queen Proserpina to send me some of her beauty." Psyche's heart sank. No human had ever gone to the underworld and come back alive. Just then, a mysterious voice spoke to her.

---

"Take a coin for the boatman," the voice said. "If you pay him, he will carry you across the river to the underworld. Take a cake too. Give the cake to the three-headed dog who guards the entrance, and he will let you pass. Most important of all, once Proserpina puts beauty in the box, do not open it!"
Psyche followed the voice's advice. She traveled safely to the underworld. Queen Proserpina gave her the box of beauty for Venus. But Psyche wondered what was inside the box. She lifted the lid and looked inside. A deep sleep came over her right away. She fell to the ground.

---

Luckily, Cupid was watching over her. Even though he was upset with Psyche, he still loved her very much. When he saw her lying on the ground, he felt pity for her. He lifted the sleeping spell and Psyche woke up. "See what happens when you are too curious?" Cupid said with a smile. Psyche smiled back at him.
Psyche brought the box to Venus. Then Cupid went to Jupiter and asked to marry Psyche with the king of the gods' blessing. Jupiter agreed. He let Psyche drink ambrosia, the special drink of the gods. The ambrosia made Psyche immortal like the gods. So Cupid and Psyche were married and lived happily ever after.
question: In the sentence 'Each ant carried a seed,' what type of word is 'carried'?
option_1: A describing word that tells what the seeds looked like.
option_2: An action word that tells what the ants did.
option_3: A naming word that tells who helped Psyche.
option_4: A connecting word that joins two ideas together.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. 'Carried' is not a describing word (adjective). Describing words tell about nouns, like 'tiny ant' or 'small seed.' The word 'carried' tells what action the ants performed.
option_2_explanation: Correct! 'Carried' is an action word (verb) that tells what the ants did. Just like 'aid' means 'to help' in the reference, 'carried' describes the action of the ants moving seeds from one place to another.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. 'Carried' is not a naming word (noun). The naming words in this sentence are 'ant' and 'seed,' which name the things in the sentence. 'Carried' tells the action those things performed.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. 'Carried' is not a connecting word (conjunction). Connecting words join parts of sentences, like 'and' or 'but.' The word 'carried' tells what action happened.
differentiation_notes: Targets identifying verb in sentence from paragraph 2 - differs from reference which asks about using verb 'aid' in different contexts
homogeneity_check: all choices are types of words/parts of speech
specificity_check: all provide complete grammatical categories with examples
length_check: A: 10 words, B: 9 words, C: 8 words, D: 8 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each describes different word type (adjective, verb, noun, conjunction)
single_correct_check: only B correctly identifies carried as an action word/verb
diversity_check: focuses on identifying word type - different from reference's contextual verb usage

question: Read this sentence from the story: 'Venus was confident that she could give Psyche a task that was too hard to finish.' Which word from another sentence means almost the same thing as 'confident'?
option_1: Jealous - when Venus 'was still jealous of Psyche's beauty'
option_2: Shocked - when 'Venus was shocked to find the work was done'
option_3: Sure - as in feeling certain or believing strongly in something
option_4: Mysterious - when 'a mysterious voice spoke to her'
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. 'Jealous' means wanting what someone else has or feeling envious. This is different from 'confident,' which means feeling sure or certain about something. Venus being jealous describes a different emotion than being confident.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. 'Shocked' means very surprised or startled. This is the opposite of confident - when you're confident, you expect something to happen; when you're shocked, you didn't expect it at all.
option_3_explanation: Correct! 'Confident' means feeling sure or certain about something. When Venus was confident she could give an impossible task, she felt sure or certain that Psyche would fail. 'Sure' and 'confident' both describe believing strongly that something is true.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. 'Mysterious' means unknown or unexplained. This is unrelated to 'confident,' which means feeling sure or certain. Something can be mysterious (unknown) whether or not someone feels confident about it.
differentiation_notes: Targets synonym relationship for 'confident' from paragraph 1 - differs from reference which examines using 'aid' as verb in contexts

specificity_check: all provide word with context example at similar detail
length_check: A: 11 words, B: 11 words, C: 10 words, D: 8 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each word represents different meaning (envious, surprised, certain, unknown)
single_correct_check: only C provides a synonym for confident

question: Why does Cupid wake Psyche up even though he is upset with her for opening the box?
option_1: He realizes that Venus has been treating Psyche unfairly all along.
option_2: He still loves her very much and feels pity when he sees her sleeping.
option_3: He wants to punish Psyche himself instead of letting the spell continue.
option_4: He needs Psyche to bring the box back to Venus to complete the task.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While Venus does treat Psyche unfairly, the text doesn't say this is why Cupid helps. The passage states 'Even though he was upset with Psyche, he still loved her very much. When he saw her lying on the ground, he felt pity for her.'
option_2_explanation: Correct! The text clearly explains Cupid's motivation: 'Even though he was upset with Psyche, he still loved her very much. When he saw her lying on the ground, he felt pity for her.' His love and pity make him lift the sleeping spell.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Cupid doesn't want to punish Psyche. The text shows he helps her because he loves her and feels pity, not because he wants to punish her. He even smiles at her after waking her.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While Psyche does need to return the box, the text explains Cupid's motivation as love and pity, not practical task completion. He wakes her because of his feelings, not because Venus's task needs finishing.

question: How does Venus's treatment of Psyche affect what happens in the story?
option_1: It causes Psyche to discover she has magical powers to complete impossible tasks.
option_2: It leads to Psyche receiving help from creatures and mysterious voices that allow her to succeed.
option_3: It makes Cupid immediately stop loving Psyche and leave her forever.
option_4: It forces Jupiter to punish Venus for being cruel to a human woman.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Psyche doesn't discover magical powers - she succeeds because others help her (ants, the voice). Venus's impossible tasks lead to Psyche receiving help, not to Psyche gaining powers.
option_2_explanation: Correct! Venus gives Psyche impossible tasks, which causes others to help her. The ants come to help with the grain sorting, and a mysterious voice gives advice for the underworld journey. Venus's harsh treatment leads directly to these helpers appearing.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Cupid already left Psyche before she goes to Venus - this happened in Part I. Also, Cupid never stops loving Psyche; he watches over her and eventually saves her, showing his continued love.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Jupiter doesn't punish Venus. Instead, Jupiter helps Cupid and Psyche by allowing their marriage and giving Psyche immortality. The story doesn't show Jupiter taking action against Venus.
differentiation_notes: Targets cause-effect relationship of Venus's actions across paragraphs 1-3 - differs from reference which focuses on Psyche's emotional journey

question: What do Psyche's actions throughout the story reveal about her character?
option_1: She gives up easily when tasks seem difficult and always needs others to solve her problems.
option_2: She is determined to succeed but sometimes makes poor choices because of curiosity.
option_3: She trusts Venus completely and believes all the tasks will be fair and reasonable.
option_4: She becomes angry at everyone who tries to help her during her journey.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Psyche doesn't give up easily - she walks day and night searching for Cupid, attempts the grain task, and travels to the dangerous underworld. While she receives help, she shows determination by trying, not by giving up.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The story shows Psyche's determination through her persistent search for Cupid and her attempts at impossible tasks. However, it also reveals her flaw: curiosity leads her to open the box despite warnings, showing she sometimes makes poor choices.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Psyche doesn't trust Venus - she knows Venus is jealous and is trying to give her impossible tasks. The text states she 'knew she could never finish this job' and that 'Psyche's heart sank' at the underworld task.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Psyche doesn't become angry at her helpers. She accepts help from the ants and follows the mysterious voice's advice. The story shows her accepting assistance gratefully, not rejecting it angrily.

question: Based on what happens when Psyche receives the box from Queen Proserpina, what can readers conclude about following instructions?
option_1: Instructions should always be ignored if you are curious about something.
option_2: Following instructions exactly is important even when you don't understand the reason.
option_3: Instructions given by mysterious voices are never helpful in dangerous situations.
option_4: Following instructions only matters when someone is watching you do a task.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. The story teaches the opposite lesson - Psyche's curiosity leads her to ignore instructions ('do not open it'), which causes her to fall into a deep sleep. Ignoring instructions because of curiosity causes problems, not solutions.
option_2_explanation: Correct! Psyche was clearly instructed not to open the box but didn't understand why. When she ignored this instruction due to curiosity, she fell into a deep sleep. This shows that following instructions is important even when the reason isn't clear, because there may be important consequences.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The mysterious voice's instructions were very helpful - they allowed Psyche to safely travel to the underworld and return. The problem occurred when Psyche ignored part of the instructions (not opening the box).
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. No one was watching when Psyche opened the box, yet ignoring the instruction still had serious consequences (falling asleep). The story shows that instructions matter regardless of whether someone is watching.
differentiation_notes: Targets conclusion about instructions from box incident in paragraphs 3-4 - differs from reference which asks about direct consequences of opening box

single_correct_check: only B accurately reflects the lesson demonstrated by Psyche's experience

question: Why is it important to the story that Cupid was watching over Psyche when she opened the box?
option_1: It shows that Cupid planned for Psyche to open the box so he could rescue her.
option_2: It allows Cupid to save Psyche from the consequence of her curiosity, leading to their reunion.
option_3: It proves that Cupid no longer cared about Psyche and wanted her to fail.
option_4: It demonstrates that Cupid was working together with Venus to test Psyche's obedience.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Cupid didn't plan for Psyche to open the box - he was upset when she did. The text says 'Even though he was upset with Psyche,' showing this wasn't part of a plan. He rescued her because of love, not because of planning.
option_2_explanation: Correct! Cupid watching over Psyche is crucial because it allows him to save her when her curiosity causes trouble. His rescue leads to their reunion, conversation about curiosity, and eventually their marriage. Without Cupid present, Psyche would have remained asleep and the story couldn't reach its happy ending.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The opposite is true - Cupid watching over Psyche proves he still cared deeply. The text states 'he still loved her very much' and 'he felt pity for her,' showing his continued care, not a lack of it.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. There's no evidence Cupid worked with Venus. Venus gave Psyche the tasks to make her fail, while Cupid helped Psyche succeed by lifting the sleeping spell. They were working against each other, not together.
differentiation_notes: Targets narrative importance of Cupid's presence in paragraph 4 - differs from reference which asks what physically happens when box opens

specificity_check: all provide complete narrative explanations with similar complexity

semantic_distance_check: each explanation presents different story interpretation (planned rescue, true rescue, abandonment, collaboration)
single_correct_check: only B correctly explains the narrative function of Cupid's presence

passage_text:
Cupid and Psyche, Part II
    
    
        When Cupid left Psyche, she felt very sad. She looked for Cupid everywhere. She walked during the day and night. But she could not find her lost love anywhere. Finally, Psyche went to Venus's temple. She asked the goddess to help her find Cupid. Venus did not want to help. She was still jealous of Psyche's beauty. Venus was confident that she could give Psyche a task that was too hard to finish.
Venus led Psyche to a huge pile of grain. The pile had wheat, millet, barley, and lentils all mixed together. "Sort all the grains into separate stacks by morning," Venus ordered. Then she gave a mean laugh and disappeared. Psyche saw millions of seeds in the pile. She knew she could never finish this job. She sat down and began to cry.

---

Then something amazing happened. Through her tears, Psyche saw one seed moving, then another, and then many more. An army of ants had come to aid her! Each ant carried a seed. Working together, they sorted all the seeds into separate piles. In the morning, Venus was shocked to find the work was done.
"Your next task will be much harder!" Venus said. "Take this box to the underworld and ask Queen Proserpina to send me some of her beauty." Psyche's heart sank. No human had ever gone to the underworld and come back alive. Just then, a mysterious voice spoke to her.

---

"Take a coin for the boatman," the voice said. "If you pay him, he will carry you across the river to the underworld. Take a cake too. Give the cake to the three-headed dog who guards the entrance, and he will let you pass. Most important of all, once Proserpina puts beauty in the box, do not open it!"
Psyche followed the voice's advice. She traveled safely to the underworld. Queen Proserpina gave her the box of beauty for Venus. But Psyche wondered what was inside the box. She lifted the lid and looked inside. A deep sleep came over her right away. She fell to the ground.

---

Luckily, Cupid was watching over her. Even though he was upset with Psyche, he still loved her very much. When he saw her lying on the ground, he felt pity for her. He lifted the sleeping spell and Psyche woke up. "See what happens when you are too curious?" Cupid said with a smile. Psyche smiled back at him.
Psyche brought the box to Venus. Then Cupid went to Jupiter and asked to marry Psyche with the king of the gods' blessing. Jupiter agreed. He let Psyche drink ambrosia, the special drink of the gods. The ambrosia made Psyche immortal like the gods. So Cupid and Psyche were married and lived happily ever after.
question: What does Psyche's decision to open the box after successfully completing both tasks show about her character development?
option_1: She has learned to always follow all instructions no matter what happens.
option_2: She remains curious and impulsive despite having faced many dangers already.
option_3: She has become brave enough to disobey any warnings she receives from voices.
option_4: She trusts that Cupid will always rescue her whenever she makes mistakes.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Opening the box proves Psyche hasn't learned to follow all instructions - she was specifically told not to open it but did anyway. This shows she still struggles with following instructions when curious.
option_2_explanation: Correct! Despite successfully completing two difficult tasks and receiving help that required following advice, Psyche still opens the box when told not to. This shows her character flaw of curiosity and impulsiveness persists even after dangerous experiences, demonstrating she hasn't fully overcome this trait.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Psyche being brave isn't why she opens the box - curiosity drives her action. Also, she doesn't disobey the earlier warnings from the mysterious voice; she follows that advice successfully. Her disobedience here is specific to her curiosity about the box.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. There's no evidence Psyche expects Cupid to rescue her. She doesn't even know Cupid is watching. She opens the box because of curiosity about its contents, not because she trusts someone will save her.
differentiation_notes: Targets character development analysis from box incident in paragraph 3 - differs from reference which asks about factual outcome of opening box
homogeneity_check: all choices are interpretations of character development/learning
specificity_check: all provide complete character development assessments with similar detail
length_check: A: 12 words, B: 12 words, C: 13 words, D: 12 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each interpretation differs (learned lesson, persistent flaw, increased defiance, reliance on rescue)
single_correct_check: only B accurately interprets the evidence of unchanged behavior
diversity_check: analyzes character development arc - different focus from reference's immediate consequence question

question: How does the author use the box incident to connect different parts of the story together?
option_1: The box connects Psyche's tasks from Venus to her final reunion and marriage with Cupid.
option_2: The box proves that Venus and Cupid were working together all along to help Psyche.
option_3: The box shows that Queen Proserpina was the most important character in the whole story.
option_4: The box demonstrates that following instructions always leads to immediate rewards and success.
option_1_explanation: Correct! The box incident connects multiple story elements: it's the final task from Venus (connecting to earlier challenges), it brings Cupid back to save Psyche (reuniting them after their separation), and it leads directly to Cupid asking Jupiter for marriage approval. The box serves as the turning point that brings all story threads together.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Venus and Cupid don't work together - Venus tries to make Psyche fail while Cupid helps Psyche succeed. Venus sends Psyche to get the box hoping she'll fail; Cupid rescues her when she falls asleep. They have opposing goals.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Queen Proserpina is a minor character who appears briefly to give Psyche the box. The box incident is important, but it centers on Psyche's choice and Cupid's rescue, not on Proserpina's importance to the overall story.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The box incident shows the opposite - Psyche doesn't follow instructions (she opens the box), which leads to trouble (falling asleep), not immediate rewards. She only succeeds because Cupid rescues her, not because following instructions led to success.
differentiation_notes: Targets narrative structure/connection in paragraphs 3-5 - differs from reference which asks about isolated consequence of opening box
homogeneity_check: all choices are explanations of story connections or narrative structure
specificity_check: all describe complete narrative connections with similar complexity
length_check: A: 14 words, B: 14 words, C: 13 words, D: 11 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each focuses on different connection (plot convergence, character collaboration, character importance, moral lesson)
single_correct_check: only A accurately describes how the box functions as narrative connector

passage_text:
The Sword of Damocles
    
    
        Have you ever wished you could be a king? Does that seem like the best job in the world? Well, before you decide, listen to this old story. A Roman writer named Cicero told this story more than two thousand years ago.
Damocles was a friend of Dionysius, who was the king of Syracuse. This was a big city in southern Italy. Damocles looked at his friend's life and felt jealous. He would envy the king because he thought the king had everything good in life. The king had lots of money, a big palace, and all the power he wanted. What could be better than that?

---

"You think I'm lucky?" Dionysius said to his friend one day. "If you really think so, let's switch places. You can sit on my throne. Try being king for just one day. Then tell me if you still think I'm the lucky one."
Damocles said yes right away. He was very excited to live like a king, even if it was just for one day. He thought it would be the best day of his life.

---

When the special day came, Damocles told servants to bring him the finest clothes. He ordered them to make a great banquet with lots of delicious food. He wanted expensive wine and beautiful music too. He sat back in the king's chair, sure that he was the happiest person in the whole world.
Then he looked up at the ceiling. He gasped in fear! Above his head was a sharp sword. It was hanging from the ceiling, held up by just one thin piece of horse hair. The sword would dangle right over his head. Damocles could not speak. He could not eat any of the good food. He could not enjoy the music. He was too scared to even move.

---

"What is wrong, my friend?" asked Dionysius.
"How can I conduct my life with that sword hanging above me?" Damocles asked. "It might fall at any time!"
"How indeed?" answered Dionysius. "Now you know what it feels like to be king. That sword hangs over my head every minute of every day. There is always a chance the thin hair will break. An advisor who helps me might turn against me. An enemy might try to hurt me. I might make a bad choice that causes my downfall. You see, my friend, when you have power, danger comes with it."
question: What does Damocles do when he first sees the sword hanging above him?
option_1: He asks the king to remove it immediately.
option_2: He freezes and cannot enjoy the banquet.
option_3: He orders servants to cut the horse hair.
option_4: He laughs and says it makes him nervous.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While Damocles does speak to Dionysius about the sword, he doesn't ask him to remove it immediately. He first becomes paralyzed with fear. Review paragraph 3 to see his initial reaction when he looked up.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The text explicitly states that after seeing the sword, 'Damocles could not speak. He could not eat any of the good food. He could not enjoy the music. He was too scared to even move.' This shows he froze in fear and couldn't enjoy anything at the banquet.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Damocles does not give any orders about the sword or horse hair. He becomes too frightened to do anything. Reread paragraph 3 to see what he actually does when he notices the sword.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Damocles does not laugh at all. The text says 'He gasped in fear' and was 'too scared to even move.' This shows terror, not amusement. Look at paragraph 3 for his true emotional response.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 3, focusing on Damocles's immediate physical and emotional reaction to seeing the sword - differs from reference which asks about Dionysius's motivation for the lesson
homogeneity_check: all choices are actions Damocles might take upon seeing the sword
specificity_check: all describe specific behavioral responses with similar detail
length_check: A=8 words, B=9 words, C=8 words, D=9 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: distinct actions: asking for removal vs. freezing vs. ordering servants vs. laughing - no overlap
single_correct_check: only B is supported by text evidence in paragraph 3
diversity_check: targets paragraph 3 character reaction - completely different from reference about Dionysius's teaching motivation
